title: labour party brexit betrayal sun says opinion
story: They claim to vote down Theresa May’s Brexit deal in the national interest.But their motivation is transparent, and shameless. They want to crash the Government, trigger a General Election, and reverse the referendum result.Senior Labour frontbenchers have said, on several occasions, that they’ve got no problem with the withdrawal agreement. And yet in their droves they voted it down on Friday, regardless of the .million votes cast nearly three years ago to leave the EU.It’s all very well for the Tories to simply assume that Jeremy Corbyn et al will never get near Downing Street – but it would be criminally complacent.We’ve more or less given up on the Brexiteers who refuse to vote for the PM’s deal, even though their preferred “no deal” is essentially impossible.But those who are tempted to plump for a permanent customs union in today’s ridiculous indicative vote process must also realise that they could very well trigger an election, with unknowable consequences.We are at a crucial moment in our history, and the stakes couldn’t be higher.WHEN the Tory leadership contest begins, it is an opportunity for the party to remind the country what it stands for.You can forgive the public for forgetting. Recently, the “small state” party has been more interested in bans and taxes than delivering for ordinary people.So it’s heartening to hear Liz Truss talk about radical overhauls of the planning system and slashing tax. Whoever mounts a challenge for the top job must present a compelling vision of what the Tory party can and will deliver.More of the same won’t be enough.FACEBOOK supremo Mark Zuckerberg wants governments to step in to police the wild west of social media.He’s right that he and his well-paid colleagues have totally lost control, with his social network flooded with terrorist propaganda, hate speech and conspiracy theorists. title: shopping centre escalator mum drops baby
story: The four-month-old tot fell two storeys to the shopping centre floor and died, according to reports.It happened at Zhenxing Shopping Square in Changping, southern China, on Saturday.Security camera footage captured the moment the child slipped from the mother’s arms.She can be seen stepping on the escalator with her older son by her side and her baby cradled in her left arm.Then she stumbles forwards and the infant falls out of her grasp and over the railing.The shocked mum and brother can then be seen sprinting down the steps.Another clip seconds later shows the pair crying on the floor near where the baby fell.Authorities said paramedics rushed to help but in the end could not save the child, who was declared dead.The police are investigating.Last year a nine-year-olds leg was crushed when his boot got stuck in an airport escalator in Vancouver, Canada.In , CCTV showed a mum trip over her dress and drop her baby ft from an escalator at a shopping centre in Uzbekistan.And in  a grandmother slipped on an escalator and dropped a baby three storeys to his death in Shanghai.

title: line of duty series five masterpiece ally ross
story: So any minute now...“There’s an RTC up ahead.” “Three FOs dead at the scene.” “ED-’s in the hands of the OCG.”The calling card of Line Of Duty which, to widespread annoyance, the BBC has advertised these past few weeks as coming: “From the makers of Bodyguard.”It didn’t. Bodyguard came from the off-cuts of Line Of Duty and it should be eternally grateful for the association.Line Of Duty is a television masterpiece and the opening episode of the fth series was a genuine TV event that, despite a whf of plot familiarity, had me reeled in before the end of the opening credits.That was as long as it took the show to introduce Stephen Graham, who’s giving a mesmerising performance as Detective Sergeant John Corbett, the UCOwho appears to have gone rogue with an OCG .There are lots of other new faces as well, including: A gang of bikers, with no bikes, who appear to have been styled by Vyvyan from The Young Ones.Slippery police spokesman Sindwhani, played by Ace Bhatti. PC Jane Cafferty, whose le was spared in the opening hijack scene by “gangster” Lisa McQueen.And the slightly robotic Detective Superintendent Alison Powell, who’s in charge of Corbett’s “Operation Peartree” and is yet another of those department chiefs who seems strangely drawn to “Ted” .A hell of a trick for a TV show to pull off, introducing them all while still tying up the loose ends of series four and leaving viewers to guess which painkillers managed to get DS Arnott out of that wheelchair and whether Hastings’ faulty hotel toilet cistern is critical to the new plot. Or just a faulty hotel toilet cistern.The fact Line Of Duty did it, however, is entirely down to the constants that have driven this show ever since its first series.It starts, obviously, with a thrilling and complex script from Jed Mercurio, who clearly gives not a stuff for any of the lazy, modern, right-on conventions of TV writing.It’s all about the story that demands the total attention of the viewers and gets the performance of their lives from the actors.Not just the newcomers, like Stephen Graham, but regulars Martin Compston and Vicky McClure, as Arnott and Fleming, who have the hardest job in drama, unravelling the plot for the audience.Without them there would be no room for the show’s crowning glory, Super-intendent Ted Hastings, who is that rarest thing in contemporary TV drama, a strong male lead.There used to be lots of them, obviously. Now we’re generally reduced to murderers, rapists or, at best, jaw-flexing “Yes, ma’am” dogsbodies, like in Bodyguard.The joy of Hastings is that the part gets the performance it deserves from Adrian Dunbar, who’s from Northern Ireland, so he was born sardonic and can give a whole new edge to lines like: “Listen Alison. I didn’t float up the Lagan on a bubble.”Together, show and actor are a dream to watch and should be the agenda-free blueprint every new drama aims to emulate.So enjoy Hastings and Line Of Duty while you can. Nothing this good is coming our way soon .The darkly funny Blue Planet Live moment when a seagull swooped down and ate one of the turtle hatchlings, just after Liz Bonnin had suggested it might live for “ years”.RE: Blue Planet Live, Steve Backshall concluding his last report with: “Steve B, signing out.”Suggest: Steve B, signing on.BBC’s This Time With Alan Partridge finished a bitterly disappointing run last night having lost about half its viewers along the way.And it’s not hard to see why, either.The funniest thing about the show was its reputation. The jokes were nearly all overdone or “borrowed”, none of it had the painful ring of truth of the Linton Travel Tavern series, from , and it never laid a glove on This Morning or The One Show, let alone its main satirical target Good Morning Britain.But then, how the hell can you get excited about Jennie Gresham accusing Alan Partridge of fancying her when, on the real thing, Susanna Reid described Piers Morgan as “an HR claim waiting to happen”, after she asked, “is Phil and Holly like this ” and he replied, “it’s like this, only without the sex”.Out loud. Live on air. At .am. Good Morning Britain is beyond parody, beyond Thunderdome even, and, with the exception of Line Of Duty, my favourite thing on telly .Tipping Point, Ben Shephard: “The meat from which bird is traditionally included in the Scottish soup called cock-a-leekie ”Liam: “Lamb.”The Chase, Bradley Walsh: “What Birmingham football team has been English champions seven times ”Katie: “Coventry.”Celebrity Chase, Bradley Walsh: “A ‘Trumpkin’ is what vegetable carved into resembling Donald Trump ”Christian O’Connell: “Turnip.”Bradley Walsh: “What Himalayan mountain is often described as the world’s highest garbage dump ”Christian O’Connell: “The Andes.”LUGE World Cup, Eurosport’s Colin Bryce: “Oskars Gudramovics and Peteris Kalnins spank it hard at the top of the hill. But will that slow them down ” Discuss.BLUE Planet Live was one of those breathtaking BBC ventures where they fly a group of presenters to three fantastically far-flung corners of the world and then spend four nights lecturing the rest of us about the evils of global warming.An irony completely lost on the hosts themselves, who were all having far too much fun in the sun to bother about their own carbon footprint.Liz Bonnin, was oohing and aahing over turtle hatchlings, on Australia’s Great Barrier Reef.Bull sharks were stubbornly refusing to eat Steve Backshall, who was squeaking away at BBC viewers from the Bahamas.And Chris Packham was chasing shadows, in a helicopter, above Mexico’s Sea of Cortez, having been told “There’s a  per cent chance of seeing a blue whale.”Nice workyou can get it.On a purely technical level, though, it was going OK until the second night, when the Mexican satellite link packed in and we were suddenly flitting haphazardly between a weirdo who collects whale snot and Costas the Mediterranean monk seal, before Chris Packham, reappeared, at the death, with a question-begging update.“Unfortunately, we haven’t found a blue whale . . . but we did record one yesterday.”In which case, what the holy harpooning hell is the point of filming it live EastEnders. It’s here for a long time, not a good time.The Voice judges uttering not one word of even mild criticism over an entire hour and three-quarter semi-final.Sally Lindsay’s Bake Off Suffragette cake putting in a strong claim for the emptiest political gesture of all time. Anyone who thinks The Big Narstie Show made the Bafta shortlist on merit.All Together Now judge Geri Spice Girl asking “What’s middle-aged ” .And BBC’s New World Order guests Sara Pascoe, Lucy Prebble and Kiri Pritchard-McLean all doubled-up laughing at Frankie Boyle’s observation it’s only Michael Gove’s glasses that stop his face, “looking like genitalia”.’Cos, for those of you struggling to place their names, they’d be just three of the people who’d be screaming for bloodanyone said the same thing about Diane Abbott and claiming: “Only female politicians get judged on their appearance.”THIS Morning, Wednesday, Schofield: “Is scheduling sex helpful or harmful  At : we’re joined by Vanessa Feltz.”Harmful. No matter what time, she’s ready.This Morning, Phillip Schofield: “Are you sure people aren’t ready for an Alan Titchmarsh album ” Blue Planet Live, Steve Backshall: “I don’t want to step on a shark, that would be a bad start.”And Piers Morgan: “If I go into a petrol station I go for Mini Cheddars or Hula Hoops.”See also: Doughnuts, sausage muffin, a breakfast bap, Cornish pasty, a couple of Magnums, two steak melts, four hot dog croissants, a cinnamon whirl or three, the Wild Bean Cafe meal deal and some crisps. No petrol.Jermaine Jenas: “Brighton are going to have to not show something we haven’t seen yet.”Jack Sullivan: “You either sink or swim and I’ve done a bit of both.”And Neil Warnock: “The equaliser was the winning goal.”THIS week’s winner is James Arthur and Dexter, from Dexter’s Laboratory.Sent in by Reenie E, via email.Picture research, Alfie Snelling. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: schoolboy scars iphone battery explodes face
story: A TEENAGE boy was left with horric scars on his chest and is lucky to have his sight after an iPhone  battery exploded in his face.Jay Watson, , from Brisbane, Australia, was fiddling with the battery on Sunday night when it burst into blame.The blast singed his hair before spraying corrosive battery acid on his chest.Jay told News: I wanted to see what was inside.I just bent it and once I did it just exploded... It was a bang and then a huge flame of fire.His mother Kari Lashbrook said she heard him scream in agony and immediately phoned an ambulance.The lad was rushed to Royal Brisbane and Womans Hospital and bandaged up before being released.Doctors told him he was lucky the acid hadnt landed on his face or eyes.Kari said: He could have lost his eyesightthe splats of acid hit his eyes as opposed to his chest.The volatile nature of the components used to make lithium ion batteries have led to phone manufactures and authorities issuing warnings to customers.Jay added: I probably should have Googled it first.Last year shocking dashcam footage captured the moment an iPhone exploded inside a womans car as she drove on a busy Chinese highway.Horrying video shows the device exploding and engulfing the windscreen in flame as the terried motorist hit the breaks.The incident happened months after another iPhone exploded into a fireball in a phone shop in Las Vegas.An employee was sitting close by when it set alight and jump out of the way as a high cloud of smoke rose from the mobile.

title: new pre eclampsia test halve time pregnant women
story: The pre-eclampsia check will be available across the NHS after a successful trial.The condition affects up to one in ten pregnancies, triggering high blood pressure and severe headaches. But one in  cases can lead to organ damage and fits, with expectant mums and their babies both at risk.Every year around , tots and seven women die.King’s College London experts developed the new test that speeds up diagnosis from four days to two. It slashes the risk of complications by  per cent.A study following , women with suspected pre-eclampsia revealed measuring levels of the protein placental growth factorin their blood provided the most accurate diagnosis.Previously medics monitored blood pressure and checked for protein in a woman’s urine.The trial ided the group in two, according to The Lancet.Docs using PlGF tests pinpointed pre-eclampsia in . days, compared to . days for traditional methods. Prof Lucy Chappell said: “We knew monitoring PlGF was an accurate way to help detect the condition but were unsure whether making it available would lead to better care. Now we know that it does.”NHS England’s Prof Tony Young said: “The evidence shows widespread PlGF testing could save  lives. It is fantastic news. The NHS . . . will be making this test more widely available.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: britain betrayed farcical commons stalemate
story: They wanted immigration control: Corbyn says No. They wanted freedom from EU courts: Corbyn says No.They wanted to stop paying Brussels billions: Corbyn says No. They wanted control over our economic future: Corbyn says No. They wanted MPs to respect the referendum: Corbyn says No.In fact, he now wants a second vote.Labour finally turned against Brexit by backing the deviously mistitled “Common Market .”. title: kickboxing mum claimed disability benefits
story: Tammy Horton,, claimed her chronic pelvic disease and fibromyalgia meant she could barely walk with sticks.She said she was stuck in her pyjamas all day because it was too painful to get dressed and could not even collect her own prescriptions.But the mum posted pictures of her in a gym while she trained daily with two local kickboxing clubs.She regularly appeared in her local paper after winning medals in bouts - and even posted pictures of her out clubbing with pals on a hen-do.DWP officers were tipped off and began investigating the fighter, who was claiming disability living allowance and Personal Independent Payment .During a two-year period they found she competed in the  CIMAC British Open, at Windsor, and Northamptonshire Open tournament.She won a silver medal at a tournament in Solihull in January  competing for the Boston Evolution Martial Arts Club.The following month she was a runner-up in her category at an international event held at Watford. She also competed for a Spilsby club.Lisa Hardy, prosecuting, told Lincoln crown court “She claimed disability living allowance and subsequently PIPs over a three year period.“She said she had serious and chronic conditions. She said she was limited to walking with crutches or using a wheelchair and that she was on morphine to control the pain.”Miss Hardy said that back in October  the DWP received a complaint that Horton’s benefit claim was fictitious but at the time she told investigators that the complaint was malicious.She said: “In February  she made a complaint for PIP. A health assessor came out to see her and she confirmed the extent of her illness.“She completed a y application process and in interview she had such severe pelvic inflammatory disease that it affected her mobility.“She said she was in constant pain every day. She said she did her food shopping online or sometimes would do click and collect. She said her husband would collect her prescription.“She told how she would live in her pyjamas for the majority of the day because it was too painful to get dressed, Lincoln crown court heard.“She said she didn’t like going out because she was too anxious. She said she would struggle to walk more than  metres.“She was asked to perform a number of physical tasks which she said she could not complete. As a result she was awarded PIP.“An investigation subsequently showed that Miss Horton as far back as January  had in fact joined a kickboxing club and was a regular member.“She received grading certicates and competed in competitions. This was a lady who expressed that she needed an extra banister fitted just to be able to get up and down stairs.“She was placed under surveillance. That showed her driving to drop off her children at school and shopping. She was seen walking independently without support.“She was brought in for interview but denied claiming any benefits dishonestly. She said her pain ied but was always there.“She said she had attended kickboxing clubs in Spilsby and Boston saying that it gave her mental focus.“This was a deliberate misrepresentation given to the health assessor. The answers were very detailed. They were backed up in interview verbally and on paper.”In total she received benefits totalling £, to which she was not entitled.Judge Andrew Easteal, passing sentence, accused her of extraordinary arrogance and deceit, adding: This was a planned, detailed, gross deception that went on for several years. It was just inexcusable.”Horton, Stickney, Lincs, admitting charges of failing to noty the DWP of a change in circumstance between  February  and  March .She also admitted making a  statement to obtain PIP between  March  and  May . She was given a  month jail sentence suspended for two years.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: driver parked grave mothers day manchester southern cemetery
story: Selena Zafar, , was visiting her mothers grave at Southern Cemetery in Manchester on Sunday when she came across the black Kia vehicle.It was left with two of its wheels on the grassy area of a grave at the Nell Lane end of the cemetery and just a matter of yards from the headstone.Selena was so outraged she took photos and tweeted them in a complaint to Manchester city council before what she describes as a “mature” couple got in and drove away.Town hall chiefs have now reminded people to park considerately at Southern and all of their cemeteries, especially at poignant times of year.Selena told the M.E.N: There is no excuse for driving over let alone parking on a grave.There are plenty of spaces outside the cemetery and yesterday most people parked outside and walked in.It’s a busy time and it’s lovely that people are remembering their missing relatives.However people need to think about others.Would they like itsomeone drove over or stopped on their loved ones grave  I don’t think so.I’m sad that in  people can be this selfish and have zero respect not only for the dead but their living relatives.I was shocked to see that it was a mature couple who got in and drove away.So often younger generations are blamed for bad behaviour but these two were old enough to know better. title: royal marines could be kitted out with 340k iron man flying suits to ambush enemy ships
story: The -printed suits could be worn by elite troops to assault an enemy ship, MoD sources said.Royal Navy top brass will also get £m for combat drones and mine-hunting robots defence secretary Gavin Williamson revealed.He said: “Our competitors are moving fast - so we need to move faster.”During a visit to Portsmouth, Williamson saw hoverbikes, wave gliders and Gravity’s Iron Man flying suit up close.The suit was flown by -year-old engineer Alex Wilson, from London, who said it was “like riding a bike.”Williamson later rubbished suggestions just one of Navy’s two aircraft carriers would come into service after The Sun revealed the Treasury had been asking questions about running costs.He said: “It would be bizarre and stupid to look at canning one of those air craft carriers after that multi-billion point investment.”He confirmed both will, “sail across the globe flying the flag for Great Britain.”Meanwhile a new unit called NavyX - drawing in military experts, civil servants and entrepreneurs - will get some of the cash to identy and buy cutting edge drone war gear to fast track into the hands of sailors and marines.Williamson, who also witnessed a host of drones that could one day be on the Navy’s order books, said: “Imagine a world in which autonomous surface vessels tow ultra-modern synthetic aperture sonars at speed to detect those deadly devices then deploy unmanned underwater vehicles to destroy them.“In many ways it sounds like science fiction. But this is a reality we will make happen.”He added: “We’ve got to be ambitious, we’ve got to be bold, we’ve have to be the revolutionaries.“The Royal Navy has always been at its best when it has been willing to embrace new technology. When we do it the world will look to us to lead as the global Britain we truly are.”Some of the money will go on developing two new autonomous mine-hunters. The vessels will be able to search further and faster for longer, while reducing risk to sailors.Currently mine-hunters are operating in the Gulf keeping shipping clear. And Williamson said the new drone iants could be in service doing the same job within three years.Williamson said the world was becoming more perilous, citing the greats from global terror, mass migration, climate change and the rise of “aggressor nations.”But he said the new investments would keep the Navy, “ahead of the curve”.The boost comes from a £m Transformation Fund set aside from the defence budget for modern new kit.First Sea Lord Admiral Sir Philip Jones, said: “From the invention of the steam catapult and aircraft carrier, to the first use of sonars and torpedoes, the Royal Navy has a strong pedigree in the development, testing and introduction of new technologies that help us keep our country safe.“Across the generations, our willingness to embrace innovation has kept us one step ahead of our adversaries, and to assure our continued success on operations into the future it is vital that the Royal Navy continues to be equipped with the latest cutting-edge capabilities.We need to address the rapidly evolving challenges that pose a threat to our national interests around the globe.”

title: madeleine mccann cops test dna samples
story: US forensics expert Dr Mark Perlin reckons new techniques could blow the case wide open - but says detectives snubbed his offer to analyse samples for free.The evidence relates to swabs lted from the McCann familys holiday flat and hire car after snfer dogs allegedly detected the scent of death.Portuguese police sent samples to by analysed by the UKs Forensic Science Service in Birmingham.Senior scientist Dr John Lowe told cops some DNA components matched Maddies - but the samples were too complex for meaningful interpretation.But Dr Perlin believes the methods used at the time are now out of date, reports Australias Nine News.He claims his Pittsburgh lab Cybergenetics, which helped identied   victims, can routinely unlock the kind of samples the FSS struggled with.The latest episode of Nine Newss Maddie podcast reveals detectives on Scotland Yards Operation Grange probe were told a year ago of Dr Perlins advanced techniques and his offer to re-test samples - but did not respond.Further enquiries about Dr Perlins offer by Nine.au last week also went unanswered, the site claims.Successful analysis of the DNA could potentially transform the worlds most famous missing persons case by confirming or conclusively ruling out key lines of enquiry.Cops reached a dead end when the tests came back inconclusive  years ago.One crucial swab was from the boot of a silver Renault Scenic that Kate and Gerry McCann leased  days after Madeleine vanished in Praia da Luz.Dr Lowe told Portuguese police at the time: Lets look at the question that is being asked. Is there DNA from Madeleine on the swab It would be very easy to say Yes simply because of the number of [DNA] components within the result that are also in her reference sample.Ultimately, Dr Lowe said the FSS could not answer that critical question because the lab was unable to separate a mix of DNA components from at least three peopleDr Perlin, who has worked with police forces around the world, claims his advanced computer software can interpret complex results like these in a way that was not possible in .He told Nines podcast investigation: If a lab can produce informative data, evenit is complex and mixed, but they cant interpret it then you can have tremendous injustice - of guilty people not being convicted, or innocent people staying in prison.What is needed is an objective and accurate interpretation that can scientically resolve the DNA.The Met Police said: The investigation into the disappearance of Madeleine McCann remains ongoing. We are not providing a running commentary.Kate and Gerry McCann have repeatedly denied any involvement in their daughters disappearance and were cleared of wrongdoing.Police believe Madeleine was snatched by a paedophile or a member of a trafficking gang.Scotland Yard is waiting hearthe Home Office will grant a further £, to continue its £million search for another  months.

title: smokers who switch to vaping save at least 346 a year study claims
story: Researchers who carried out a detailed study found the financial implications of buying packets of fags is one of the main consideration for those who now vape instead.As well as saving cash, smelling better and no longer having smoker’s cough were also hailed as reasons why people have switched.The £-a-head figure means the .million people who vape are a collective £. billion better off, according to the report.The poll of , Brits who are in the process of, or have made the swap from smoking to vaping, found more than half switched to save money.Other positives of abandoning cigarettes include having better teeth and breathing easier, according to three in .A further  per cent said they feel less stressed and over two thirds said they would ‘never’ go back to smoking.The research was commissioned by the UK Vaping Industry Associationand mark the beginning of VApril, the brand’s vaping awareness campaign.TV doctor Christian Jessen, who is supporting the campaign, said: “There are now over three million vapers in the UK who have made that le changing decision to switch from smoking.“But yet, according to Public Health England, an incredible  per cent of smokers have never even tried vaping.“VApril aims to change this by encouraging more smokers to consider making that switch to a far less harmful alternative.”The research also found since saving cash, three in  have saved up for a holiday and put money into a savings account.E-cigarettes have proved a huge help with giving up smoking, as  per cent admitted before this option existed they would have never been able to quit.A huge eight in  would recommend converting to vaping to those who are trying to quit.Similarly, one in five said making the switch has given them a greater sense of taste.As well as health worries, over half admitted the worst things about smoking included the effect on their fitness, the bad smell and financial impacts.A further  per cent said they are more confident in social circles since switching and one in five said they feel more accepted by friends and acquaintances.This compares to an astonishing eight in  who felt judged by people when they smoked.Before vaping, other popular tried and tested methods were revealed as nicotine patches, medication and  per cent even went cold turkey.Top reasons for converting to vaping include breaking the habit of smoking as  per cent admitted they knew it wasn’t good for them and three in  had heard vaping was the most effective cessation tool.Of those who have successfully switched,  per cent have convinced other smokers to do the same.On average, those polled used to get through a staggering , cigarettes a year.The study, conducted via OnePoll, revealed seven in  converted to vaping because of the VApril campaign.John Dunne, a director at the UKVIA, said: “The research highlights there are so many le-changing benefits to switching to vaping, more than just our health, from money to enjoying family time.“It also highlights just how much of a financial effect giving up smoking has on an inidual.“It’s impactful on someone’s appearance as it helps them feel less conscious about their smell, teeth and skin.“Our VApril campaign wants to emphasise the best things about making the change from cigarettes to vaping and help smokers quit for good.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: girl horrific infection walking barefoot muddy pigsty
story: The -year-old was diagnosed with a parasitic infection caused by sand fleas, which burrow themselves into the skin.Her family brought her to a primary care clinic  days after travelling to rural Brazil where she had played in a pigpen without shoes on.Doctors in the case, reported in the New England Journal of Medicine, found multiple itchy pauples, with black dots in the middle.They said the infection is known as Tungiasis, an inflammatory skin disease caused by a sand flea native to Central and South America.The infection is more common in remote or poverty-hit areas, they said.The female sand flea buries itself deep into the skin, usually in the toes, soles and heels, according to the World Health Organisation .It then sucks on blood and its body quickly begins to grow, which can cause itching, inflammation and pain.The flea then lays about  eggs through a tiny hole in the skin, which fall to the ground and hatch.Treatment generally consists of surgically extracting the burrowed sand fleas and applying topical antibiotic.Without treatment, the parasite dies within about three weeks and symptoms begin to regress, which means the disease will clear up on its own, according to a report in PLOS Neglected Tropical Diseases.However in poverty-stricken areas, people tend to get reinfected and can end up with hundreds or even thousands of sand fleas embedded in their skin, it said.The WHO estimates that around  million people are at risk of the infection int he Americas.Its unclear exactly how the young girl in the new report was treated, however medics said the sand fleas were removed from multiple lesions.

title: youtube craze drinking bottles water
story: The trend seems incredibly boring, but there is an extreme element to it - some YouTubers are filming up to six videos a day, racking up thousands of videos on the site.Commitment and stamina are the entertaining aspects of the trend, rather than the content of the videos, and some are chugging over four litres a day.One vlogger, who posts under the alias Aaron drinks water, is the most regular water-drinker online and is currently on his ,th video.He reportedly downs ml of water six times a day, filming each session on his phone to be uploaded to YouTube.Although hes the most regular uploader, having been in the game for only two years, hes in second place when it comes to the number of videos uploaded to his channel.Aaron, , was inspired by the original water-drinking video-maker, Jon Drinks Water, who has amassed , videos over a period of six years.Speaking to The Times about this inspiration, Aaron said: “For some reason it intrigued me . . . that he had thousands of videos often with no views.So I decided to start my own channel and drink more than other water drinkers. I think it’s cool that I can look at a video and see myself and where I was a year or two ago.”Although the growing number of water-drinkers - who all use the same username format of X Drinks Water - compete to upload the most videos to their channels, they are supportive of each other to keep the trend alive.The tight group includes names Alexander Drinks Water, Nick Drinks Water and even an elusive Windows Drinks Water.As the creator of the trend with the most videos uploaded, Jon is the leader of the pack and supports the others by linking their channels alongside his videos.He has even created a leader-board of who has uploaded the most videos and how frequently.Aaron said: “I often comment on other people’s videos and we did a new year special recently which was organised by Jon.“When we reach milestones we congratulate each other.”In one video, Aarons ,th, he took on an extra challenge - to down . litres of water.In the video he pauses to say to the camera Im gonna die and definitely gonna die once the bottle is empty.He says hes neutral about the drinking itself and that his motivation is the feedback and the challenge.This is the latest in bizarre trends to take over the teen-vlogging community.In  the Tide Pod Challenge flooded the internet and left hoards of teens eating laundry detergent pods, making themselves very unwell.Manufacturer Tide even launched a page on its website dedicated to the safe handling of its products and warns parents to keep them out of reach of children in a bid to stop the craze." data-credit"" data-sizes"auto" data-img"https:www.thesun wp-content uploads   water.jpg stripallw" src"data:image svg+xml,%Csvg xmlnshttp:www.w.org  svg viewBox  . %E%C svg%E" John Drinks Water is yet another account following the trend

title: girl scalped go kart accident hair caught motor
story: Lani Use, five, was riding on a -year-old gasoline-powered go kart at a family party when her hair became caught in the vehicles exposed motor belt.Her head was pulled backwards in the accident, fracturing her skull in four places and ripping the right side of her scalp off from her hair line to her neck.Mum Macie Gautreaux, , was walking a few feet ahead of her daughters four-wheeled go-kart, designed for children, when she heard her family members scream.The mum and her husband Jacob Use, , watched in horror as Macies stepdad, Jason Blanchard, , freed an unconscious Lani from the motor by cutting her hair with a kne.The parents rushed Lani, whose brain and skull were exposed, to their local hospital in Houma, Louisiana, USA, before she was airlted to Ochsner Medical Center in New Orleans.Lani underwent a five hour emergency surgery on October  to repair lacerations to her brain and bind her fractured skull together with six dissolvable plates.Plastic surgeons were able to manipulate Lanis remaining scalp to cover her wound, saving the five-year-old from a painful skin graft.Mum Macie said: It was terrying. It was like a horror movie.She was riding in circles on turtle mode on my brothers old go kart. It was going slow enough that we could walk right beside her.I was walking in front of her when I suddenly heard screaming.When Lani let her head fall back her hair became trapped in the motor belt behind her and it pulled her whole head back.The right side of her scalp was just hanging off. It was ripped from the front all the way to the nape of her neck.She was drting in and out of consciousness and her eyes were rolling into the back of her head.My mum was screaming at someone to get a kne or scissors.My stepdad physically cut her hair with a kne.The ambulance was taking so long that we bundled her into a car and brought her to the hospital which was a mile away.We had to hold her scalp to her head with a towel because you could see her skull and her brain.Her injuries were too serious for the hospital to handle and she was airlted to New Orleans almost immediately.Lani was booked into surgery the next morning and it was a really dficult night.She was in the ICU and her heart rate was dropping, as well as her oxygen levels.They were trying to keep her up because when she fell asleep her vitals went nuts. I thought I would lose her.The five-year-old pulled through the complex surgery but doctors were unable to determine the long term extent of her brain damage.Since the accident, Lani experiences small focal seizures up to three times a day which doctors are currently investigating.The kindergartener, who ed to school in December, struggles with weakness on her left side due to nerve damage and has trouble with her vision.Macie, a loan specialist, said: She has little seizures everyday which doctors are investigating.She just stares into space for a few minutes and feels very tired afterwards.We have an appointment in April about this but it is likely something she will cope with for le.Her EEG in January said her brain activity was abnormal which is worrying but we have to take each day as it comes and do the best we can for her.Macie said Lanis personality has changed since the accident and she is awaiting an appointment with a therapist to help her cope with post traumatic stress.Macie said: After the accident she was really depressed. She cried a lot and she didnt like how she looked. It was heartbreaking.Lani loved dancing and cheering before the accident. She has to be careful now with her brain injury. She cant tumble and loud noises scare her.She doesnt want to be too far away from us at any point.The couple warned parents to take safety precautions around go karts and make sure their children are wearing helmets with their hair safely tied up.Macie said: We live in Louisiana and riding go karts and four wheelers is just something we do here.After the accident I would not be comfortable with her riding one herself. I had tied her hair into a bun that day but it came loose.I would make sure childrens hair is tied up securely and they are wearing a helmet. Macie was riding the go kart on turtle mode and this still happened.Even though this accident was horric, I dont think I can keep her locked up for the rest of her le.I want to share my story so another child doesnt have to go through the pain my daughter has endured.Macie and Jacob, an air conditioning specialist, welcomed their second daughter Presley in December and said Lani is the best big sister.Macie said: I was eight months pregnant at the time of the accident and I thought I would go into labour.Lani absolutely loves Presley. She is the best big sister in the world. Its so sweet. Its been some light in a truly terrible time.A spokesperson from the Houma Police Department confirmed that officers deemed the incident an accident.The Use family have set up a GoFundMe page to help raise funds to cover hospital and living expenses incurred since Lanis accident.The accident happened last October.

title: ex girlfriend all girl gang kick teen floor
story: Aimee Purdey could be heard begging please let me go as she curled up onto the floor in a desperate attempt to avoid the flailing kicks.Footage of the sickening happy slap attack was released by Aimee after the thugs responsible - led by her ex Simone McDermott - avoided immediate jail sentences yesterday.McDermott, , had lured victim Aimee to her apartment at am on the pretext of needing a shoulder to cry on - only for the victim to be violently ambushed by her and three female friends, all .As Miss Purdey curled up in a ball and begged: “Let me go, please let me go, McDermott and the other girls laughed and rained down kicks and punches while one filmed the assault on her mobile phone.The teen was so badly beaten that doctors even found footprints on her head.In the two minute video, one the attackers could be heard shouting: Giver her here - I’ll have a go whilst another said: Im gonna break your face.Miss Purdey was left with multiple bruising to her head and body and underwent a CT scan in hospital after doctors found footprint on her forehead.One of her finger nails was so badly damaged in the assault, it fell off her finger.Melissa Marriott and Siobhan Wait, both of Blackley, and Victoria Houghton, of Wythenshawe, admitted assault with intent to rob and were given suspended sentences at Manchester Crown Court.They were also ordered to perform up to  hours unpaid work each and must give Aimee a total of £, compensation.Both Marriott and McDermott said they had believed Aimee had intimate pictures of them on their phone at the time of the attack.They both sobbed in the dock as Judge Timothy Smith said Marriott had orchestrated a pre-planned, vicious, cowardly ambush and assault.But Aimee, from Denton, said she was horried by the suspended sentence handed down by the judge.The young woman, now , told Manchester Evening News: I wanted them to docustodial sentences. They were saying in court they are young and that they have been through stuff but Ive been through stuff.I dont go around battering people or jumping on people or even being mean to people.Im annoyed about . I just dont think justice has been fully served.The court heard McDermott had been in a relationship with Miss Purdey but began an affair with college student Marriott whilst the victim was on holiday in Spain.In a statement Miss Purdey, , a bartender said: I thought they wanted to kill me - I could have died. I had a lot of pain with my injuries and I was unable to leave my room for two to three weeks - when I did go out I had to have someone with me.She said she had even started getting her shopping delivered as she was so scared to leave the house.McDermott initially claimed Miss Purdey had attacked her and her friends intervened but she later admitted the assault.

title: turtle graveyard sipadan island malaysia
story: Photographer Josh Vergara, , from The Philippines, discovered the tomb of dead reptiles on Sipadan Island in Malaysia, while on holiday on March .He said the shelled mammals die after becoming lost and trapped in the cave, meaning they neverto the surface to breathe.Joshs disturbing images show numerous turtle skeletons lying on the floor of the Indian Ocean.He said: Turtle Tomb in Sipadan is the only known turtle graveyard in the world.The cave system is often visited by turtles as they need to breath but after getting lost in the cave, they finally find a spot to lay and rest for eternity.It was quite scary as we headed dark caverns and as we got in deeper into the caves, we found more and more turtle remains.The chilling graveyard was first spotted by legendary ocean explorer Captain Jacques Yves Cousteau in the s.He believed that the turtles in the cave had gone there to die peacefully.However, according to locals in Sipadan Island, the reptiles became disorientated and died of asphyxia.A skeleton of a dolphin, which is also believed to have suffered the same fate as the turtles, also lies in the cave which reaches up to  metres in depth.

title: explosion russia military space academy
story: Local news sites said up to four cadets were injured and  people were trapped in the rubble at the Mozhaisky Academy.Officials from Russias FSB spy agency were reportedly at the scene along with police and emergency rescuers.Unveried reports suggested a historic bomb was discovered by staff and it detonated when they tried to move it.A warning alarm was sounded to evacuate the building before the explosion, according to local media.Russias defence ministry later confirmed three people were taken to hospital with non-le threatening injuries.It added an unidentied object went off inside the prestigious academy, but did not give further details.TV channel  News said the blast caused a staircase to collapse, trapping  people on the upper floors of the faculty building.The aerospace engineering college, named after aviation pioneer Alexander Mozhaisky, is one of Russias largest universities and provides training for astronauts, air defence forces and security agencies.Alexey Morenets, the GRU agent accused of a bungled cyber attack in the Netherlands, was a student there.

title: heatwave jellyfish invasion uk
story: Hundreds of barrel jellyfish were found across the South West coast as the warm spell sent plankton levels soaring.Parts of the country saw highs of C weather last week, making the country hotter than Australia.One marine enthusiast said hed seen more of the creatures - the largest jellyfish found in UK seas - in the last three days than all of the previous  years.Rupert Kirkwood wrote on his blog, The Lone Kayaker: There are more barrel jellyfish around the coast of SW England than I have ever seen in -plus years of sea kayaking.I have seen more in the last three days than all the other years added together …  on Tuesday, + on Wednesday and + today.While it is common for large numbers of jellyfish to be spotted together, the size of the barrel jellys makes it a truly a spectacle, Rupert said.Rupert added: Their appearance seems to have coincided with a plankton bloomthat has probably been caused by the sunny weather.He believes there could be millions in our waters.As I paddle along I can see jellyfish beneath the surface up to about ft from my kayak, so I only see a tiny fraction of the vast numbers out there.The three locations I have seen them over the last three days are  miles apart so there must be millions of these large and mysterious creatures floating about around our coast.The influx of barrel jellyfish means a large number are being washed up on our beaches.Journalist Lee Trewhela posted images of three jellyfish on beaches on Cornwalls Roseland peninsula last Friday.AK Wildle Cruises, in Falmouth, also tweeted reports of seeing lots of huge Barrel Jellyfish offshore.Barrel jellyfish swarm in warmer coastal waters in late spring and often wash up on our beaches in May or June, sometimes in their hundreds.They are the size of dustbin lids - giving them their other common name: Dustbin-lid Jellyfish. They are attracted inshore by plankton blooms which provide a plentul supply of food.They have eight arms, each frilly in appearance. These frills actually contain their small stinging tentacles which surround hundreds of little mouths.However their sting is harmless to humans.A member of Cornwall Marine Strandings Network told Cornwall Live it was not uncommon to see so many barrel jellyfish on the countys beaches and its waters.

title: baby boy enema scalding water nurses
story: The shocking incident occurred in the Shymkent Infectious Disease Hospital in southern Kazakhstan where little Nurislam was receiving treatment for an acute respiratory infection.Mum Arainur Kalkaman said her son felt better after three days of  treatment at the hospital, until he was prescribed an enema for constipation.Nurislam started crying and screaming in pain as soon as the nurse began the procedure using hot water.Mrs Kalkaman begged the nurse to stop but she wouldnt, saying she knew better.After the procedure was finished, Mrs Kalkaman rushed to check on her child and saw he was badly burned.She said: I saw that the skin on my son’s bottom was badly burned.“His right buttock was covered with horrible giant blisters.“I cannot convey the horror that I experienced when I saw it.“I stormed into the office of our doctor shouting that they had burned my son.”Nurislam was rushed in the intensive care unit in a critical condition where he is still fighting for his le.Doctors have not commented on the child’s chances of survival yet.His heartbroken parents are pleading to Kazakhstan Healthcare Minister Yelzhan Birtanov to intervene and provide their son with the necessary medical care.Nurislam’s dad Yerbolit Samenov said: Doctors do not say much and we do not know what future holds for our son.“He was put in the intensive care unit last Thursday. Since then he has been living on painkillers.“All I know is that his condition is very grave. He is crying in pain and bleeding every time he needs to poo.”The parents reported the incident to the police and an internal investigation has been launched.The head doctor of the hospital Amangeldy Nurlybaev, has said a special commission to investigate the incident has been instigated and will involve top hospital managers.The nurse who gave the child enema has been suspended.Police are yet to comment on the incident.

title: student half dog ate mans face jupiter florida
story: Austin Harrouff, , is accused of brutally murdering John Stevens and Michelle Mishcon at their home Jupiter, Florida, on August , .He allegedly beat the couple before using scissors and a kne to kill them.Cops found the college football player covered in blood while chewing on the face of Mr Stevens while growling like an animal.Officers used Tasers and a police dog to finally overpower the student.Now a mental health report published last week claims that Harrouff was suffering from a “lycanthropy delusion” meaning he believed he was a canine at the time of the attack.Dr Phillip Resnick, from the University Hospitals of Cleveland, argues that the student was “actively psychotic” during the night of the killings.He wrote: “The fact that Mr. Harrouff persisted in biting the male victim in the presence of police officers, in spite of being shot, being tased and receiving multiple kicks to the head, suggests that Mr. Harrouff was actively psychotic.”Harrouff’s family say he has been diagnosed with bipolar disorder and was acting bizarrely before the murders claiming he “believed he was invincible.”And Dr Resnick says that the Florida State University student was suffering from a form of psychosis known as “lycanthropy delusion” in which sufferers often believe they are a werewolf.Harrouff, who was  at the time of the attack, told Resnick that he believed he could run “super fast” because he was “half-man, half-dog.”Psychosis is a mental disorder in which the person suffers from a disconnection from reality often resulting in strange behaviour.While it was initially believed that the student may have been high on drugs, an FBI toxicology report showed “no designer drugs in his system and only trace amounts of marijuana.”Dr Resnick’s -page report states that “it was unlikely that it was a drug-induced psychosis that led to the attacks,” according to the Palm Beach Post.Harrouff’s lawyer Nellie King said the “evaluation confirms Austin could not form the requisite intent to commit these crimes due to his severe mental illness.”King continued: “Austin was undergoing a psychotic event at the time of the incident and did not know that his conduct was wrong.”The -year-old has been charged with two counts of murder and one count of attempted murder for attacking a neighbour before allegedly killing the couple.His lawyers say they will use an insanity defence when he is scheduled to stands trial on November .In , prosecutors released disturbing images which show the -year-old student being handcuffed and taken away by police and with his mouth agape.

title: no deal brexit germany british expats
story: Germany’s interior ministry has called on regional authorities to guarantee the rights of , expats and their families.Officials have asked local parliaments to provide immigration services with the “necessary resources” to process Brits’ applications.Their advice includes setting up new hotlines that UK citizens can call to ask for advice on how to gain permanent residency.Under the plan UK citizens in Germany on our exit day will be granted a transition period during which they can apply for full citizenship.The new law will also make it easier for British pensioners and low earners living in the country to meet the requirements for a residency permit.German MP Franziska Brantner, said: “British citizens who already live in Germany, above all, need legal certainty.“You cannot be held responsible for the harakiri of your Government.”Meanwhile, Angela Merkel’s socialist Europe Minister Michael Roth called Brexit a “big sh**show” and blasted “over-privileged” UK Cabinet ministers.Berlin also wants to allow Brits to carry on travelling to the country without visas eventhere’s No Deal.But that will require a decision at EU level to add the UK to the bloc’s visa free travel list.Other major EU countries including France, Spain and the Netherlands have also announced plans to ensure Brits are protectedthere’s No Deal. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: theresa may summons top team for five hour brexit meeting that could decide the fate of the tory party
story: After last nights votes failed to show her a way out of the mess, the PM gathered her Cabinet for a mammoth session where Brexit could finally been decided.Ministers spent the whole morning locked in talks, before breaking for a short lunch.They went back in for another session just an hour ago, but are still holed up in Downing Street.Shes under pressure from both sides of her team over which way to turn to get Britain out of the impasse.The PM is expected to try for a fourth meaningful vote over her deal later this week - possibly being put up against a soft Brexit option to force Tories into backing her.However,that falls yet again then the way forward for her is unclear.Remainer Cabinet ministers like David Gauke and Amber Rudd are likely to push her to go for a soft exit.They could point out that during last nights votes a customs union only lost by three - making it more likely to be able to command a majority.Another Cabinet minister - a close ally of the PM’s - told The Sun: “We just need to get Brexit over the line now and worry about reshaping it later.But that option would likely split the Tories in two, as many will say it wont respect the result of the  referendum, well be tied to the EU, and unable to strike out alone.Remainer Chancellor Philip Hammond is expected to float the option of another referendum to try and break the Brexit deadlock unless anyone has any other ideas.He will tell his colleagues that unless the Government makes its own compromise proposal, it could have to put it back to the people as the party and country cant afford another snap poll.A snap election could force a way out of the deadlock by getting the public to give their support for a Brexit outcome chosen by the PM - which could be her deal or a softer one.The risks with that could backfire on the PM and see her losing seats like she did in .Several reports say the PM and her team will be shown internal polling about how the party might do in another vote.Others will argue the PM must now embrace a hard Brexit, which is technically our legal default option on April  anyway.The Sun revealed today that the PM will face an onslaught from Brexiteers who are demanding she go back to the negotiating table and try again to change the hated Northern Irish backstop.One Brexiteer Cabinet minister told The Sun: “We have to go back to Brussels and ask the EU to improve the backstop next week.“All we can do now is take this to the wire. Every other course will be a disaster.“The EU desperately want a deal. We just haven’t pushed them hard enough on this yet.International Trade Secretary Liam Fox and Development Secretary Penny Mordaunt are on resignation watch over the customs union fallback, after the Cabinets other Brexiteers were said to have begrudgingly accepted.One other option being floated is for the PM to attach her deal to her Government and dare Tories to vote it down because it would pave the way to an election.But again that would be a risky path, as some Brexiteer MPs have hinted they would vote her Government down in a crunch no confidence poll anyway.

title: theresa may brexit deal house of commons vote 4

title: uk take part eu elections
story: NewsWill the UK take part in EU elections in   What you need to knowWhen are the European Parliament elections, how do they work and who will win them ShareCommentsByOliver MilnePolitical Correspondent:,  APR Updated:,  APR NewsAcross Europe voters will go to the polls in May - will Brits  "Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe UK was not supposed to be taking part in the European Parliament elections scheduled to happen in May. Andwe had left on the original proposed Brexit date of March  then we wouldnapost have. In fact, the EU had even gone as far as to reassign our seats to other countries. But now, as MPs face yet more deadlock and Theresa May canapost find a majority for her deal, taking part in the EU-wide polls is seeming more and more like a realistic possibility. Which leads to a lot of questions - like when are they supposed to be held, andthey did go ahead, who would win  Well, read on - because weaposve got everything you need to know about the European Elections . When will the European elections happen  Across Europe, the elections to the European Parliament will happen between Thursday, May  and Sunday, May .The date will y depending on the country in line with their traditions or laws around voting. In the UK most elections are held on a Thursday - so the most likely date is Thursday, May .    Will Britain take part in the European elections  It all depends on what happens with Brexit. If Parliament agrees to a Withdrawal Agreement with the EU before our current departure date on April  then we will not take part. But any extension past April  will probably see the UK take part in the elections - and a long delay to Brexit. The UKaposs new MEPs would then sit until the UK exited the EU. The Electoral Commission has said that should the UK participate in the European election, polling day would most likely be May .  What changes and preparations have to be made to let us take part  To take part in the elections, the first thing that would need to happen is the government would need to amend legislation. This would likely happen when it made the necessary preparation to avoid leaving with No Deal. So it would happen on - or as close as is practical to - April th. Councils would then begin rushed preparations, with the support of the Electoral Commission, to make sure all the paperwork, polling stations and volunteers were in place for an election. Cabinet Office minister David Lidington gave council ing officers authorisation to pave the way for elections from April .    Last year the government gave the Electoral Commission £, to pay for its “activities relating to a European Parliamentary election in ”, meaning preparations were already underway. The deadline for candidates to submit their MEP nominations would be on April . On the EUaposs end, Britainaposs seats in the European Parliament have currently been redistributed to other member states - proportionally based on population. But they looked ahead and have written into the rules a way to dely that reallocation until Britain formally leaves the EU, meaning some MEPs from other countries may take their seats only after the UK leaves. How do the European elections work  The UK currently has  seats in the European Parliament, just under % of the  who make up the total. Unlike in Westminster elections, people donapost vote for a single candidate in their constituency.    Instead, the UK is ided into twelve constituencies. They are the nine English regions, Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland. Each is given a number of seats based on how many people live there. MEPs in the UK are elected by a closed proportional list system. Meaning the parties submit a list of their candidates for a region and the number of MEPs they see elected is based on the share of the vote they get.  Regions and the number of MEPs they elect East Midlands -  East of England -  London -  North East England -  North West England -  South East England -  South West England-  West Midlands -  Scotland -  Yorkshire and the Humber -  Wales -  Northern Ireland -  What is the current state of the British parties in the European Parliament  Labour  are the biggest British party in the European Parliament with  seats. The Tories have , the SNP have two, Greens three, Sinn Fein one and the Ulster and Democratic unionists have one apiece. But this is totally dferent from when the elections were held in . The biggest party then was UKIP, who won  seats and .% of the vote. But since then they have totally collapsed. Concerns over the partyaposs new hard-right direction and a number of personal squabbles.    The then UKIP party leader Nigel Farage now leads a group of nine defectors as the Brexit Party. UKIP has just seven MEPs left with other sitting as independents or one as a representative for the new SDP.   Who would win the election and are the parties ready  Basically, this is impossible to tell at the moment. Some people argue that fuelled by the idea of Brexit betrayal the elections would be a bonanza for far-right parties standing on a promise to fight the establishment. Others argue that because Brexit is such a big issue in British politics turnout would be a lot higher than the average as people would view it as a proxy for another chance to have their say on Brexit. Not that much polling has been done on the European elections but an opinion poll done for The Observer in March had Labour % ahead in the polls, with the Conservatives on %.    Rumours have been floating around that the Conservative Party has begun the process of preparing - and they have already asked their MEPsthey would stick around to stand again. Labour hasnapost said much about its election prep but it is understood to be making preparations for the pollsthey are needed. And The Independent Group, set up by MPs who defected from Labour and the Conservatives, applied to register as a political party in order to be able to fight European electionsthey take place this year. The group will stand under the party label Change UK - The Independent Group

title: voice mirror theresa mays brexit
story: NewsopinionVoice of the Mirror: Theresa Mays Brexit is a national humiliationAsking the people what theyd like, in a general election, could never guarantee a radically dferent Parliament but its better than any other optionShareCommentsByVoice of the Mirror:,  APR Updated:,  APR NewsopinionMay should now listen to MPs "Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailFour days after Britain was supposed to leave the European Union it is clear Theresa May is part of the problem and increasingly unlikely to find a solution. To call the entire Brexit process a shambles is no exaggeration. The chaos created by an incompetent Prime Minister, a collapsing government and the warring Conservative Party are a national humiliation. There is no guarantee a general election would produce a radically dferent Parliament or a route forward but asking the people what they would like is better than any other option. In the meantime, we urge May in the days and weeks she has left in Downing Street to listen to MPs and stop offering herself as a hostage to hard-line Brexit no-dealers both in her own party and Northern Ireland’s DUP.     One of the tragedies of this ordeal is that votes like those tonightwere not called two years ago to try to find a consensus. Twisting kne Theresa May, first as Home Secretary and now Prime Minister, should accept her share of responsibility for the surge in kne crime. Conservative governments have squeezed pay and pensions of teachers and nurses for nine years. Now, suddenly, they have been put on the frontline in the battle against crime. It is nothing more than rank hypocrisy The facts speak for themselves when May has issued marching orders to , police officers, punching holes in the thin blue line. story: NewsJellyfish the size of BIN LIDS invading UK shores after mini heatwaveAn army of barrel jellyfish, the largest found in our waters, have arrived earlier than usual after the unusually warm weather of recent weeksShareByLee Trewhela, Joe Smith:,  APR Updated:,  APR NewsThe huge barrel jellyfish have been appearing on our shores in large numbers "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailJellyfish the size of BIN LIDS have invaded UK shores after our mini heatwave sent plankton levels soaring, it has been claimed. Rising temperatures brought an abundance of food for the marine animals - sparking the largest barrel jellyfish influx in  years. Hundreds of the animals were found washed up across the South West coast following our warm spell. And one marine enthusiast said heaposd seen more of the creatures - the largest jellyfish found in UK seas - in the last three days than all of the previous  years. Rupert Kirkwood wrote on his blog, The Lone Kayaker: “There are more barrel jellyfish around the coast of SW England than I have ever seen in -plus years of sea kayaking.    aposaposI have seen more in the last three days than all the other years added together …  on Tuesday, + on Wednesday and + today.”Rupert added: “Their appearance seems to have coincided with a plankton bloomthat has probably been caused by the sunny weather .”He believes there could be “millions” in our waters. “As I paddle along I can see jellyfish beneath the surface up to about ft from my kayak, so I only see a tiny fraction of the vast numbers out there.    “The three locations I have seen them over the last three days are  miles apart so there must be millions of these large and mysterious creatures floating about around our coast.” The influx of barrel jellyfish means a large number are being washed up on our beaches. Journalist Lee Trewhela posted images of three jellyfish on beaches on Cornwallaposs Roseland peninsula last Friday. AK Wildle Cruises, in Falmouth, also tweeted reports of seeing lots of “huge” Barrel Jellyfish offshore. Barrel jellyfish warm in warmer coastal waters in late spring and often wash up on our beaches in May or June, sometimes in their hundreds.    They are the size of dustbin lids - giving them their other common name: Dustbin-lid Jellyfish. They are attracted inshore by plankton blooms which provide a plentul supply of food. They have eight arms, each frilly in appearance. These frills actually contain their small stinging tentacles which surround hundreds of little mouths. However their sting is harmless to humans. A member of Cornwall Marine Strandings Network told Cornwall Live it was not uncommon to see so many barrel jellyfish on the countyaposs beaches and its waters.

There was plenty to find out: which is the best of all the clubs  Which Spoons has the best carpet  And how will eating at Spoons five days on the bounce make me feel  This is how I got on. It was a journey... Monday – aposChips cooked to perfectionapos   Spoons of choice:  The Commercial Rooms, Corn Street Meal:  Hummus and roasted vegetable wrap with chips and an orange Sanpellegrino .Given its prime location, Corn Streetaposs Wetherspoon restaurant is the chainaposs flagship Bristol branch, so it felt right to start my week here. Like many Spoons out there itaposs a grandiose building steeped in history, which somewhat juxtaposes what Spoons offers, some might say. Since there are no clubs on Mondays I thought Iaposd get the ball rolling with a veggie option before the unavoidable onslaught of meat came my way. And with a giant mural of Isambard Kingdom Brunel looming over me, I felt like I should order something a little more on the classy side to impress the big man. A hummus and vegetable wrap washed down with a San Pellegrino it was, then. Perhaps naively I thought I was going for a fairly healthy option by swerving a burger or something of that ilk, but my first thought as I bit into the wrap was salt. So much salt. Still, aside from that it wasnapost bad and I couldnapost help but enjoy the overall meal, especially as it came with the luxury of a San Pellegrino - arguably the most premium of all the fizzy beverages. And the chips were cooked to perfection, too - something which I later discovered isnapost always the case. For under a fiver I couldnapost really fault it. The Commercial Rooms got things off to a good start. Tuesday: Steak Club – aposPretty tasty but slightly greasyapos   Spoons of choice:  The Knights Templar, Temple Quay. Meal:  oz sirloin steak with chips and a pint of Shipyard American Pale Ale .This Spoons dfers from most others in Bristol, and indeed across the country, in that it doesnapost quite boast the same impressive architecture and could instead be mistaken as an office by passers-by,it were not for the neon green Spoons sign. Its location means it is often packed with workers from the cluster of nearby offices and commuters. When I went on Tuesday lunchtime there was just a smattering of lonesome diners - myself included. I was pleasantly surprised when the waitress behind the counter asked how Iaposd like my steak cooked, having gone in with the assumption a Spoons steak is a Spoons steak is a Spoons steak. But no, my slab of meat arrived promptlyand cooked as I had asked, and while it obviously wasnapost to the same standard as the cuts you get at the likes of The Ox, Mugshot or Pasture it was pretty tasty,not slightly on the greasy side. The chips were once again very enjoyable, the mushroom and peas were decent too, but the tomato was not. The pint of Shipyard, something youaposd often pay around £ for alone, made the £. fee an absolute steal. I was fairly impressed with the first club of the week. Wednesday: Chicken Club – aposFull yet disappointedapos  Spoons of choice:  The Berkeley, Park Street Meal:  Pulled chicken burger with chips and a pint of diet Pepsi .As a big poultry fan, Chicken Club was the one I was most looking forward to before I embarked on my Wetherspoon journey. The cycle across town to Park Street ramped up my hunger levels a notch or two and I was ravenous when I ordered my pulled chicken burger. My excitement was slightly dampened when I was informed that they had run out of the Jack Daniels honey glaze sauce a colleague had recommended. That was only a minor setback, however, compared with the awful chips that came with my burger. Unlike the previous two days they were disastrously undercooked and some were even stone cold. I probably should have mentioned something to one of the members of staff buzzing about but, given my hunger, I forced them down. The chicken was okay but covered in far too much barbecue sauce, and the bun it was served in was poor - barely toasted and a little on the stale side. I cycled back to the office, full yet disappointed. Chicken club had let me down. Thursday: Curry Club – Curry with a side of plastic Spoons of choice: Knights Templar, Temple Quay Meal: Rogan Josh with naan bread and poppadoms, washed down with a ginger beer . There was one key dference between my visit to the Knights Templar on Tuesday and my Thursday jaunt - on Tuesday there wasnapost a piece of plastic in my food. Yes, thataposs right, there I was happily enjoying my curry when I discovered a piece of plastic packaging underneath my naan bread.The irony is that I was just saying to my girlfriend, who had kindly joined me for lunch, it was the best Spoons meal Iaposd had all week thanks to succulent pieces of lamb and a tasty, perfectly spiced sauce. A minute before unearthing the unwanted item. Undeterred, I cracked on with the meal - having put the plastic to one side - and didnapost bother the waitress with a complaint, despite Rachael advising otherwise. J.D.Wetherspoon has since issued an apology, which is nice, and explained the packaging wasnapost used to wrap any of the mealaposs contents but instead came from a container in the kitchen. Friday: Fish Friday – The best food all week, but the worst service Spoons of choice:  The WG Grace, Whiteladies Road Meal:  Fish and chips with mushy peas and a pint of Brewdog Punk IPA .Before I get stuck into Fridayaposs review, I thought Iaposd describe my Thursday evening jog. I felt incredibly sluggish, having to stop for a walk after only about  minutes. Who knows, maybe it had nothing to do with the Spoons food but usually I feel much fitter when going for a run towards the end of the week, so by my reckoning it was probably the change in diet that made me feel like I was running with lead in my trainers. So thereaposs your aposscientic proofapos,you wanted it, that eating at Spoons every day doesnapost do wonders for your fitness levels. Anyway, The WG Grace proved to be hot and cold. It produced the best food I ate all week by a country mile, but was also where I found the poorest service.    Shortly after taking my seat, a waiter strolled past and plonked a plate of chicken wings in front of me. He was pretty much halfway across the restaurant before I could tell him they werenapost mine. Then a few minutes later a waitress askedthe wrap she was holding was what I had ordered. It wasnapost, so she took it back to the kitchen having not been able to locate its owner. And then, to complete the hat-trick of mishaps, my plate arrived with peas instead of the mushy peas I had ordered. The waitress wasnapost too happy about having to go and get it changed. However once my dish arrived- which I ordered using the impressive Wetherspoon app for the first time - it was top notch. The batter on the fish was nice and flaky and the chips were the best Iaposd eaten all week - far better than the soggy abominations I was served on Wednesday. After finishing my meal I felt a little bit sick, to be honest, and truly stuffed to the brim. I think I was done with Spoons by this point and could tell my body was craving some fruit and veg. What did I learn  The chips DO have an off-day The under-cooked, soggy excuses I was served at The Berkely proved this. More restaurants should adopt Spoonsapos approach to condiments I absolutely HATE those pathetic little pots of Ketchup and other sauces you get served at some restaurants, but at Spoons there are bottles of sauce filled to the brim everywhere you look - and not the cheap stuff, either. Bravo, Tim Martin, bravo.  Spoons carpets are WILD The carpets at Spoons are pretty impressive, arenapost they  I would love to know where they source them from.  Fish club is the best of all the clubs The fish and chips at The WG Grace were pretty darn good, it was just a shame about the shambolic service. Combined with a pint of Brewdog Punk IPA, it was my favourite meal of the week. Plastic and rogan josh isnapost a good combo Fortunately I didnapost eat the bit of plastic that was in my curry on Thursday afternoon, but it was still a little off-putting and made me question the care taken by kitchen staff.  Five days of Spoons isnapost conducive to a healthy lestyle This is hardly surprising, but I did not feel great after eating five Spoons lunches. As I waddled back to the office after my fish and chips on Friday, I was ready for a break from Spoons, dreading my fitness levels for Saturday morningaposs football match. Spoons service is hit and miss Over the week I found the service to be a mixed bag. Some staff were friendly but others were downright rude. The best were at the Berkely worst at the WG Grace.
