title: east-lothian-council-lar-housing-rejected
story: Housing charity LAR had applied to build four houses and  flats on the land, which is designated for business use, in Prestonpans but has failed to find an employer to take it on.Despite a personal plea from the charityrsquos chief executive and an admission that East Lothian Council had tried to buy the site for housing itself just two years ago, the affordable housing bid was rejected at a meeting of the councilrsquos planning committee on Tuesday.The decision came despite LAR revealing it had invested pound, in preparing plans for the site after it was told the council would consider a change of use.Chief executive Ann Leslie told the committee that out of  homes built or under construction by the charity since it began,  had been in East Lothian and there were currently  people on its waiting list to move into one in the county.And she revealed the charity has been considering moving its base to East Lothian.She said: ldquoWe are very keen to support East Lothian as much as we are able to bring as many affordable homes as we can. There is a big waiting list in the county and we hope to open a base here.But planning officers urged councillors to reject LARrsquos proposals, regardless of their own efforts to build housing there two years ago.Iain McFarlane, head of planning, said that two years ago the council did not have its Local Development Plan approved and faced a shortage of land for affordable housing.Now the plan had been adopted, he said there was sufficient land supply for the next five years.He said allowing housing on the site would set an ldquoundesirable precedent, adding it would be ldquoselling our employment plans down the river.Councillor Kenny McLeod, committee member, said he was ldquodeeply uncomfortable about refusing planning permission on a site the council had tried to develop in the same way two years ago.At the time, council officers said the landowner rejected their pound, offer as too low.Robin Holder, representing LAR at the meeting, said the council had given written reassurance it would consider the site, which has lain empty since , for housing.He rejected claims that approving the plans would set a precedent, saying: ldquoThis is a small area, this site is a quarter of one per cent of land identied for industrial use in East Lothian. The site has been vacant for many years and the evidence suggests it will remain so.But Councillor Norman Hampshire said: ldquoI cannot support the application: it would send a message to other owners of land designated for business use.The committee rejected the planning application by six votes to three.Following the meeting, Ms Leslie said: ldquoNaturally we are disappointed at the decision and are considering whether to appeal against it.ldquoWe have worked very closely with East Lothian Council over the last three years on a number of projects to enhance the provision of good-quality affordable homes in the area and have enjoyed a very positive working relationship with them.ldquoOur proposal for Prestonpans was a design and build project for  homes, very similar to our recently completed development at the disused site of the former boatyard in Cockenzie. This proved to be extremely popular and was vastly oversubscribed, so there is an urgent need for homes like ours.ldquoWe understand that this site in Prestonpans had been earmarked for commercial use but, in the absence of any confirmed interest, we had hoped that our plans, which would enhance the local environment and provide much-needed affordable housing, would have been supported.

title: woman-was-five-and-a-half-times-over-drink-drive-limit-in-prestonpans
story: Gayle Duffy has been banned for  months after she was caught with mcg of alcohol in ml of breath at High Street, Prestonpans.The legal limit is just mcg.Duffy, of Clark Avenue, was also sentenced to a -day restriction of liberty order meaning she must stay within her home address between pm and am for the duration of the order.The -year-old had previously admitted the offence and she was sentenced at Edinburgh Sherf Court last Wednesday.Duffy admitted drink-driving on February .

title: east-lothian-residents-urged-to-switch-off-for-earth-hour
story: Earth Hour encourages people to turn off all non-essential lighting for one hour and is being supported by East Lothian Council.Every year, millions of people participate in the WWF global movement to raise awareness about climate change and the human impact on the earth.Major landmarks such as the Efel Tower, Buckingham Palace, Edinburgh Castle and the Sydney Opera House switch off all lights and visual displays run by electricity for the hour.Earth Hour takes place between pm and pm tomorrow.

title: asbo-bans-musselburgh-woman-from-abusive-behaviour
story: The ASBO was granted against Vivienne Stewart, , of Stoneybank Gardens South, following an application to Edinburgh Sherf Court by East Lothian Council.The court was presented with details of the alleged anti-social behaviour of Ms Stewart, which included shouting and swearing, excessive noise and reports of late-night disturbances.The terms of the ASBO ban her from behaving in a way that causes or is likely to cause alarm or distress to others, including playing a radio, TV or other sound-producing devices at anti-social levels, as well as shouting, swearing or using threatening, intimidating, aggressive or abusive language or behaviour within her home.A council spokesperson said: ldquoEast Lothian Council, with the support of Police Scotland, will not hesitate in taking robust action against those whose behaviour causes alarm and distress to others.

title: msp-hopeful-of-vastly-improved-service-at-musselburgh-gp-surgery
story: The group was highlighted by Colin Beattie, MSP for Midlothian North and Musselburgh, who recently met Jeane Freeman MSP, Cabinet Secretary for Health and Sport, following ldquooverwhelming public concern regarding the serious lack of appointments to see a doctor and the poor level of service offered by the practice.Mr Beattie stated that a spokesperson from the medical practice, which is based at Musselburgh Primary Care Centre, indicated that ldquoimprovements in the way patients are being cared for in Musselburgh are in the process of being made.Early evaluation of the way services were being delivered since the launch of the Collaborative Working for Immediate Care service ndash run by East Lothian Health and Social Care Partnershipand the merged Eskbridge and Riverside Medical Practices ndash demonstrated that patients who previously would have seen a GP were now seeing the right clinician at the right time for their specic needs.The new service, developed in partnership by Riverside, NHS  and ELHSCP, ensured that urgent care was dealt with on the same day and patients should have ldquono anxieties about being seen by the right professional at the right time.Through this new way of delivering patient care, it not only provided an increase in the number of patient appointments with practice GPs and other healthcare professionals, but also provided an increase in appointmentfor patients with complex needs.A recent survey conducted within the practice demonstrated that more than half of patients agreed that they did not always need to see a GP.Work is also under way by ELHSCP to implement a new telephone and IT system that will support call demand into the practice.The importance of patient involvement in getting services right is ldquovery much recognised by the practice, which is encouraging residents to get involved with the Patient Participation Group.Speaking after meeting with the Cabinet Secretary, Mr Beattie said: ldquoI would like to assure all of my constituents that patient care is of paramount importance and that all agencies involved in the new way services are being delivered within Musselburgh Primary Care Centre are focused on delivering the best care possible.ldquoRiverside Medical Practice is working with other organisations to ensure that improvements are made and I would encourage anyone with any issues regarding the practice to get in touch with them and become involved with the patient participation group.ldquoI am hopeful that the improvements being made by the organisations will be seen by patients and a vastly improved service will be delivered.ldquoI will continue to closely monitor the future performance of the practice and ask patients to keep me advised on whether the improvements are working.

title: seatbelt-embarrassment-spurs-on-musselburgh-couple-to-big-weight-loss
story: Derek Melon, , a customer services advisor, and his we Carole, , a mortgage advisor, of James Street, are both feeling ldquofantastic after their bumper weight loss, which was sparked by a holiday to Florida.Derek has dropped five stones from st lbs to st lbs, and Carole, who weighed in at st lbs, lost four-and-a-half stones to get to st lbs since they joined Weight Watchers in June last year.Their journey started after the couple, who have a teenage son, booked a holiday to Florida.Carole said: ldquoI was so excited but the plane journey going left me feeling humiliated and not happy as I had to request a seatbelt extension as I could not fasten the original seatbelt. Thankfully no one heard me asking for it but the embarrassment of having to ask was enough to spur me on.ldquoAt this point, on what should have been an exciting time, I was left feeling down, and it was then that I decided that it was time to lose weight.ldquoNever again did I want to be in that position of asking for an extension. The next time I was flying I wanted to be able to buckle up like any other person.ldquoWhen I ed, I decided to join Weight Watchers at Musselburgh Hope Church, and it was the best decision I have ever made.ldquoI have now lost more than four-and-a-half stones and feel fantastic. I find the Weight Watchers app amazing as its so easy to use and being able to track is really simple and motivating.ldquoI am a very fussy eater, and, on the plan, I can still have a treatI want. This makes le easy and no one really knows you are on a healthy eating plan as I can eat just like everyone .ldquoEverything about the Freestyle plan just suits me, and, even though I donrsquot eat meat or fish, I can still eat a lot of what I like.ldquoThe weekly workshops are very motivational and I love going. My wellness coach, Lisa Stewart, is so supportive, as well as all the other members.ldquoNow I can make the right choices, walk more and shop for clothes that I would never have been able to buy before. Clothes shopping has also become really enjoyable and less expensive as I no longer need to buy a size  but a rather smaller size .ldquoWalking has now become easier as I used to get breathless but this does not happen now. I have the motivation to keep going even when Irsquove put weight on as Irsquom not perfect.Derek was inspired to lose weight by Carole, saying: ldquoMy we joined Weight Watchers and her initial weight loss was inspiring. I knew I had to lose weight but I just never had the motivation to do anything about it.ldquoMy we was looking amazing and it was then that I knew it was time for me to get on the Weight Watchers wagon. Irsquom so glad I joined with Carole as I find it easy to follow.ldquoI can still eat my favourite snacks ndash crisps ndash which is something I was not prepared to give up. Thankfully I can enjoy these and still lose weight.ldquoDoing the Freestyle plan with Carole is really good although we do not always eat the same foods. The choice of foods that we can enjoy and eat means both us can enjoy what we want.ldquoThe support from the coach Lisa is fantastic and sometimes Irsquom the only male who stays for the weekly talk. This does not phase me as my weight loss is too important and everyone is really friendly. Even when my we canrsquot make it, I go on my own. Men should not be afraid of joining as Irsquove had a fantastic weight loss.ldquoMy food choices are now better and I pay more attention to what I eat. We both used to eat things like large bars of chocolate, deep-pan pizzas, lots of bread and cheese. There was no thought to what we were eating.ldquoWe now eat better with lots of fresh fruit and veg, and have more thought in what we are preparing and eating and are both enjoying our food much better.He added: ldquoA big tick to myself is that I can now buy jeans in Primark ndash something I was not able to do before. It sounds silly but being able to go and buy a  waist instead of a -inch waist just makes me smile. My top size used to be an XXXL but can now buy a size XL L, so itrsquos quite clear why I enjoy buying new clothes.

title: tims-tales-the-magic-bracelet
story: THE origins of this tale came a while ago after a leg came off my daughter Manjarsquos favourite baby doll.She had been given the doll by her grandmother when she was only two years old. She called it Big Baby.She decided it was a girl and it became her favourite doll. It was soft and easy to cuddle, and Manja would take it with her everywhere.After years of being carried, played with and subjected to all manner of pampering with nail polish and make-up, the condition of the doll began to deteriorate.Then one day, Big Babyrsquos right leg came off! The seam holding the leg had torn and repeated repairs failed.At that time, I suggested we could replace her. But my daughter looked at me in horror: ldquoJust because she has one leg doesnrsquot mean I love her less.I remember being stung by my own insensitivity. Big Baby was not just an old doll, and I should have known that.Manja was six then. She is near  now. She has obviously grown in her games and play, yet Big Baby remains an important part of the family. But the loss of her dollrsquos leg led Manja into talking about disability. Over the years, it was a topic she wouldto when she was playing with her. She adapted clothes for Big Baby and refused to treat her as broken, or any less a doll.Then, recently, during one our story-making sessions together, she suddenly came up with this tale. We then wrote it down. I helped her with spelling and some phrases, but otherwise this is all her work and idea.I agree that children need to be taught empathy, but they often soon get it in ways adults forget, as I did. The discrimination and prejudice we encounter is taught by adults to children. Butwe listen to our children, they can often be the best teachers of understanding and empathy for us all.So here is Manjarsquos tale, which she titled The Magic Bracelet:Once there was an old man who had a foot which wouldnrsquot work and so he had dficulty walking.He had to use crutches and people said he was disabled, and because of this nobody would give him a job.So to get some money he would sit by the roadside and make porridge. Hersquod sell bowls of it to people who were walking by on their way to work. He told them that porridge was healthy and the best breakfast, which is true of course.So people would give him a penny for a bowl of his delicious porridge. That way he made some money.One day, while he was making his porridge, a young girl came and told him she would love to have a bowl of porridge but she had no money. The porridge maker gave the girl a kind smile.ldquoNever mind, he said, ldquoI always make extra just in case itrsquos needed.He handed her a bowl of porridge and she sat down and ate it. She was very hungry.As she gave the porridge-maker the bowl back, she noticed his crutches leaning against the wall.ldquoWhy do you have crutches  asked the girl.The porridge-maker looked sad and told her that he couldnrsquot walk very well because of his foot that wonrsquot work. He explained he needed his crutches to walk.The girl thought for a moment and smiled at the porridge-maker.ldquoI have a friend who can help you so you wonrsquot be disabled anymore, she said. The old man smiled at her, but this time it was a sad smile.ldquoThat is very kind of you, he said to the girl, ldquobut the doctors have told me that there is nothing that can be done to fix my foot, so I will be disabled for the rest of my le.ldquoPlease meet my friend, asked the girl. So the porridge-maker agreed.The girl helped him up and he walked slowly with his crutches with her. She took him to a beach.ldquoWait here, Irsquoll go get my friend, said the girl. The old man sat on the sand and waited for a long time. Eventually the girl ed.ldquoHere, she said, ldquotake my hand and Irsquoll take you to my friend. But first you must wear this shell bracelet.It was a beautul bracelet, made from dferent shells. He put it around his wrist.The porridge-maker went to pick up the crutches but the girl said: ldquoNo, leave them there, you will not need them.ldquoBut I canrsquot walk without them, he said. The girl just smiled and said: ldquoTrust me. So he did.She held his hand and slowly led him into the sea.He was hobbling at first, but the sea rose over his legs and his body got lighter in the water. Soon he was up to his waist in water.ldquoI cannot swim, said the porridge-maker, now feeling worried.ldquoTrust me, said the girl, ldquoI am wearing a bracelet as well, so we will e in together.So he trusted her and he ed into the water. Suddenly, he realised that there was some magic happening because he could breathe under the water. And he wasnrsquot cold or afraid.Then he saw the girlrsquos friend. She was a mermaid. ldquoWelcome, said the mermaid.ldquoYou see, said the girl, ldquoI told you my friend could help. The bracelet is magic, it gives you the ability to be like a mermaid and swim under the sea.The porridge-maker swam perfectly under the sea. He was not disabled under the sea. He could swim fast and he did circles and back flips. He smiled at the girl, this time a happy smile.ldquoThank you, he said. She smiled a happy smile back: ldquoMy friend said you can keep the bracelet and use it as often as you want.And so he did. And he realised it wasnrsquot his foot which made him feel disabled, but other people being unkind and making fun of him or treating him as useless.He still couldnrsquot walk well, but he knew he could breathe and swim under the water like a mermaid, while those who made fun of him couldnrsquot. And he could make the most delicious porridge ever. He understood now that although he had a disability, he was not disabled.

title: wallyfords-new-public-library-based-in-school-to-open
story: The facility has been provided as part of the new Wallyford Primary School project at Futures Way to meet the demands of major new house building in the area.The library bears the name of Margaret Oliphant, a th-century writer from Wallyford.Born on April , , she died on June , .Alister Hadden, chairman of Wallyford Community Council, has given support about local historical events which are reflected in the new building.A spokesperson for East Lothian Council said: "The community library has been named the Margaret Oliphant Library."The graphics on the internal windows, the old ship wheel from the former school badge and the external brickwork reflect aspects of Wallyfordrsquos history."This will be further developed in partnership with the community council and library over time."The library, which replaces the former library at Faside Buildings, has a separate entrance and exit when open for the public on: Monday and Tuesday, pm to pm Thursday, pm to pm Friday, am to pm and pm to pm Saturday, am to pm. The library is closed on Wednesdays.Outwith these hours, the library is available for the school to use either through class visits or for iniduals to use. Library staff are available to arrange activities such as book clubs or how to research projects.This is a "unique situation" for East Lothian as, until now, there have been separate staffed school libraries in the secondary schools and public libraries in the community.

title: new-tenants-take-over-cafe-at-dunbars-lauderdale-park
story: Bev Anderson and John Semple, , signed the lease for the cafe in Lauderdale Park last week and are already busy working to get the business open for around Easter.The couple run the Wishing Tree Play Cafe on Musselburgh High Street, which they will operate alongside the Dunbar business, named Wishing Tree... By The Sea.Bev said: ldquoWe have had the Wishing Tree coming up for four years.ldquoI actually had signed the lease four years ago for the Wishing Tree and three weeks later the lease came up on [Lauderdale Park].ldquoAt that stage, I did not think I was in a position to do it.ldquoI have been coming to Dunbar for a long number of years and had a caravan at Pease Bay.ldquoWe moved to the area and I used to take my daughters to the park. We used to play there all the time and go to the cafe and I always loved the setting and thought it had so much potential.Now, with the Wishing Tree up and running, Bev and husband John, of the townrsquos Countess Road, are excitedly working on transforming the building.A takeaway hatch is being installed, with plans for a vintage ice cream bike and ice cream to be sold.Bev, who hopes to create at least three jobs in Dunbar, said: ldquoThe reality is it is going to be fresh home-baking and local produce.ldquoWe are targeting as much local produce as we can and there are a lot of good things going on in the area.ldquoThere will be fresh homemade salads, the healthy side of things, but there will be sweets and treats as well.The business hopes to be open in time for the European Stone Stacking Championships, which takes place in the town on April  and .Bev, , will run the cafe and was keen to get involved in community events, with the possibility of food markets also being considered.The business will be open five days a week during term time and throughout the week during the holidays.Bev said: ldquoThere are a lot of local events in Dunbar.ldquoThere is Civic Week and other things and we are really keen to be part of the existing programme. There is so much going on in Dunbar and we want to be adding wee things in the future.

title: businesses-in-north-berwick-urged-to-let-people-use-their-toilet
story: The nearest public toilets to the town centre are located at the entrance to the Imperial Car Park, off Quality Street.However, anyone at the other end of High Street, particularly those heading to the townrsquos train station, have nowhere to lsquospend a pennyrsquo.Now, North Berwick Coastal Area Partnershiprsquos lsquoOn the Move grouprsquo has launched an initiative to encourage businesses on High Street and surrounding roads to make their facilities available.Premises can display a signthat simply says: ldquoYoursquore welcome to use our toilet.Hilary Smith, chairwoman of the On The Move group, was hopeful businesses would sign up to the scheme.She said: ldquoWe are delighted at the support local businesses have offered to this initiative.ldquoThe lack of toilets at our train station has been a long-running concern. We have not taken our eye off that problem, but this project ensures that people wonrsquot get caught short!One of those signing up to the scheme is the townrsquos Westgate Gallery.Roy Symon, from the business, said: ldquoWe are very pleased to share our facilities and place a sign in our window.ldquoWe want to help our visitors feel welcome and enjoy what beautul North Berwick has to offer.For more information, email nbc-ap@eastlothian.gov.uk

title: poppy-smith-close-to-pool-dream
story: Poppy Smith has been unable to swim at county leisure centres for three years after taking unwell in September .The youngster, from Gullane, was initially suffering from cold-like symptoms but woke the next morning unable to swallow or move her arm.She was diagnosed with a rare condition called acute flaccid myelitis, which damages nerves in the spinal cord.Now, the eight-year-old is continuing her recovery after undergoing an operation at Edinburghrsquos Royal Hospital for Sick Children.Her mum Laura told the Courier: ldquoUnfortunately Poppy had a tough winter with viral illnesses that affected her breathing.ldquoShe had to be hospitalised in November with pneumonia and lung collapse, and go back to having help with her breathing overnight.ldquoShe now has a non-invasive ventilator [nasal mask] to help her and she has been in great health since the start of the year. We are hoping that as she grows and her chest muscles get stronger, we can try again without the ventilator support.ldquoThe great thing about the non-invasive ventilation is that she doesnrsquot need her tracheostomy [tube in her neck] anymore and she has recently had an operation to close up the stoma [hole] in her neck and airway.ldquoThe operation went really well and Poppy is delighted with how it looks as she was always very self-conscious about the tracheostomy.ldquoNow that the stoma is closed, she is able to speak more loudly and even sing!ldquoOnce she has been given the all clear that it has healed well, she will be able to go in water.ldquoShe hasnrsquot been able to swim properly for three years and is very excited to be able to do this again!The community got behind the youngster, who is in P at the villagersquos primary school, with a series of fundraisers, collecting more than pound,.Some of the money, as well as a grant from the Jude Brady Foundation, was used to buy a hydrotherapy pool.Hydrotherapy could benefit the youngster but, unfortunately, there is only limited provision through the NHS and it involves travelling some distance.Poppyrsquos mum added: ldquoWe will then be able to do more hydrotherapy exercises with her in the pool that the Gullane community fundraised for.ldquoWe hope that this will help to strengthen the muscles in her core and arms.Last year, the youngster was part of a crowd of more than , at the Falkirk Stadium to see pop stars Little Mix.Poppy, joined by her elder sister Jessica, was able to meet band members Perrie Edwards, Jesy Nelson, Jade Thirlwall and Leigh-Anne Pinnock, famous for hits such as Black Magic, Shout Out To My Ex and Cannonball.

title: we-are-f-says-official-report-on-impact-of-brexit-on-rural-scotland
story: A document published by Scottish Rural Actionfeatured a side banner on page four with the statement.It was one of a number of banners attributed to participants in a workshop which asked them to imagine what newspaper headlines they might expect to see after Brexit.Amanda Burgauer, SRA chairwoman, said that the exercise had been used as an ldquoicebreaker and that several of the participants had used ldquoearthy language in describing their feelings towards Brexit.The comments are only explained on the following page, saying they had been put forward by those taking part in the workshop event.Ms Burgauer said that she would flag up the ldquodesign and layout issue with the SRA design team.The Scottish Government has said that although the SRA report was funded through its Brexit Stakeholder Fund, it had no editorial role.The report will be launched at an SRA event with cabinet secretaries Mike Russell and Richard Lochhead in Elgin on Monday.Its findings also detailed the potential impact of Brexit on rural Scotland, suggesting that it could lead to ldquost century clearances, with a loss of freedom of movement resulting in signicant depopulation.Further concerns raised in the report, taken from conversations with rural communities, also included the risk of EU funding being lost post-Brexit and potential damage to social cohesion.Speaking about the report overall, Ms Burgauer said: ldquoThis report is about giving voice to a rural point of view that is rooted in Scotlandrsquos people and places, rather than its rural industries.She added: ldquoThere is widespread anger and frustration across rural Scotland, but that anger isnrsquot solely about Brexit.ldquoIt was clear from workshop discussions that Brexit is compounding long standing concerns about rural equity and fragility.ldquoBrexit was described as the lsquostraw that breaks rural Scotlandrsquos backrsquo, with people pointing to structural fragilities across rural communities.ldquoParticipants generally believed that an historic over-reliance on EU funding to lsquoprop uprsquo rural areas makes rural Scotland particularly exposed to future loss of EU support.Speaking ahead of the reportrsquos launch, Constitutional Relations Secretary Mike Russell said: ldquoThe Scottish Government is committed to ensuring the voices of rural communities are heard and I commend Scottish Rural Action for the work it has done to achieve this.ldquoThe findings in this report are stark. Taking Scotland out of the EU against our will removes us from a market which is eight times bigger than the UK alone.ldquoRural communities are deeply worried about the impact of Brexit on their lives. From funding and trade to community le and the workforce, many believe the effects will be nothing short of catastrophic.ldquoThis is sadly yet another example of just how damaging Brexit will be for Scotland.A UK Government spokesman said: ldquoThriving rural areas with strong, sustainable economies and vibrant communities will continue to be a priority for the UK Government when we leave the EU.ldquoWe have committed to establishing a UK Shared Prosperity Fund, which will cover Scotland, to increase productivity in areas where the local economies are furthest behind.ldquoWe have also confirmed that we will maintain the same cash total in funds for farm support until the end of the Parliament.

title: revealed-scotlands-happiest-place-to-live-is-near-glasgow
story: Research for Royal Mail analysed eight separate measures thought to be linked to happiness, including le expectancy, crime levels and earnings.The council area south-west of Glasgow topped the Scottish list, with its position cemented by a high placing in the earnings index.Top  happiest places to liveThe area scored in the th percentile across all local authorities in the UK for income, Royal Mail said.East Dunbartonshire came second in the Scottish study after boasting low levels of crime and good access to health services.Aberdeenshire completed the top three, also scoring highly for health services.Stirling, in fourth place, was found to have a comparatively good level of earnings relative to other local authorities in Scotland.The Scottish Borders secured the next position on the list with the second lowest level of crime in Scotland, followed closely by Midlothian and East Lothian.Highlandand the Shetland Islandswere the two northernmost local authorities on the top  list.Highland had the joint highest score for reported well-being across the UK, while the Shetland Islandsrsquo low crime rate and low deprivation levels edged it past other areas.South Ayrshire finished in ninth position with its strong performance in access to local services.Winchester was declared the happiest place to live in the UK.A Royal Mail spokeswoman said: ldquoThis new study takes a look at the areas across the UK sparking the most joy.ldquoFor people across the UK looking to live in or visit the happiest places, there are plenty to choose from.Royal Mail commissioned Cebr to construct the happiness indexearlier this year.The eight measures studied were reported personal well-being, le expectancy, earnings, inequality, carbon emissions, crime, deprivation and access to health services.

title: slimming-world-weight-loss-wonder-sheds-10-stone-to-achieve-london-marathon-dream
story: Gail Tennant, , from Airdrie joined the Airdre Slimming World group in February  weighing more than st. Now she will be representing Slimming World in their national team of  slimmers from across the UK and Ireland on April th . This yearrsquos team will be the official golden Slimming World marathon team, as the organisation celebrates its th birthday year.Collectively, the team have lost more than st and will be running to raise money for Cancer Research UK and the Irish Cancer Society. The team aim to increase awareness of how keeping a healthy weight can reduce the risk of developing some types of cancer.Supporting the cancer charities is particularly important to Gail as she has seen her dad battle the disease.When first Gail joined the Airdrie Slimming World she had been running for around nine months, however struggled to get reach a certain distance with her weight and poor diet taking its toll. When she joined Slimming World, however, she found she could eat to fuel her running and lose weight at the same time.For all your breaking Glasgow news, click here, or head to our Facebook, Twitter and Instagram pagesWhen Gail began following the Food Optimising healthy eating plan, she discovered a love for cooking. She swapped her diet of chocolate, cakes and shop-bought-sandwiches for cooking healthy, wholesome meals from scratch including her favourite dish of chicken stir fry.She said: ldquoWhen my consultant explained the eating plan, I couldnrsquot quite believe that I could lose weight without going hungry, and still enjoy all my favourite meals just by making changes to the way I prepared and cooked them. Irsquove never eaten so well in my le! And I need all the fuel I can get for marathon training ndash so potatoes, pasta, and rice are all regularly on the menu! I was so nervous before joining but I soon realised I neednrsquot have been. I got a fantastic warm welcome from the group.Gail added: ldquoI canrsquot believe Irsquom running the London Marathon after where I was a couple of years ago. Irsquove completely transformed my le, really found a love for running and canrsquot wait to be running the big one this year ndash especially in Slimming Worldrsquos golden birthday year ndash is a real dream come true!Gail said: ldquoTherersquos no way Irsquod have lost st or be running the marathon without the support of my group. They are the ones who have kept me on track each week ndash both with my weight loss and with my running milestones. My group inspired me to keep going and have been there to congratulate me whenever I reach a new lsquofurthest distancersquo, lsquofastest runrsquo and lsquohalf stone awardrsquo, as well as inspiring me with their achievements on their own journeys! Theyrsquove been really generous in sponsoring me and I know theyrsquoll be cheering me on when the day comes too!Gail started with the Couch to k app, and has now completed more than  half marathons. She canrsquot wait to run her first marathon as part of the golden Slimming World team: ldquoItrsquos so special to be on the team in Slimming Worldrsquos th birthday year. Irsquom so much happier and healthier and by losing weight I know Irsquove reduced my chances of developing a range of health problems.For all your breaking Glasgow news, click here, or head to our Facebook, Twitter and Instagram pagesldquoI canrsquot wait for the atmosphere on race day and to cross that finish line. Achieving this dream would never have been possible before losing weight. Ilsquom excited to give something back and raise money for Cancer Research UK and the Irish Cancer Society as I have seen first-hand how the incredible research can help with treatment and help people beat cancer. Slimming World Consultant Lynn Johnston, who runs Gailrsquos weekly group sessions, says: ldquoGail is a real inspiration to us and we are all so proud of her. When she first came through the door she just wanted to lose weight ndash she had no idea what a huge le and fitness transformation she was about to begin and certainly no idea that she would one day be running the London Marathon, itrsquos incredible! She proves that with a little determination and the right support, anyonersquos dreams can be achieved.Anyone who would like to sponsor Gail and the Slimming World Marathon team can do so by visiting: justgiving slimmingworldlondonmarathonMoney raised will go towards Cancer Research UK and the Irish Cancer Societyrsquos le-saving research to help bring forward the day when all cancers are cured.If Gailrsquos story has inspired you to lose weight, everyone is welcome at the Airdre Slimming World group which is held at Springfield Community Centre, every Monday at .pm or .pm, alternatively the Airdrie group meets at St Columbarsquos Parish Church, Thrashbush Road every Thursday at .pm or .pm. Lynn also runs the Calderbank group, which is held every Saturday morning at am at Calderbank Parish Church Hall. For more information or to find your nearest group visit www.slimmingworld, or call   .

story: Are you ready to tee off in some of thebest courses in Scotland and Northern Ireland Take inspiration from theupcoming championship and try out some fantastic golf courses for yourself.Golf in Northern IrelandNorthern Ireland is home to some of the most spectacular golf courses in the world, including Royal Portrush, host of The th Open and Royal County Down, voted No  course in the world by readers of Golf Digest. These courses have seen home-grown talent including Rory McIlroy, Graeme McDowell and Darren Clarke hone their skills and rise to stardom thanks to the spectacular quality of their local greens and fairways.Getting to Northern Ireland from Scotland couldnrsquot be easier and with just a short hop across the water you too could be following in the footsteps of these golfing legends and making the most of the fantastic range of links and parkland courses Northern Ireland has to offer.Portstewart Golf ClubTwo-time Open champion Willie Park Jr was responsible for one of the makeovers of Portstewart Golf Clubrsquos Strand Course, which lies just  minutes from Royal Portrush and which staged the  Dubai Duty Free Irish Open. Its  holes of links golf include the Riverside Course and the original Old Course, dating from .Ardglass Golf ClubAfter a round on the short but spectacular Ardglass Golf Club links, hugging the rocky shore and clfs close to Royal County Down, golfers can raise a glass in the bar of the worldrsquos oldest clubhouse, built as a castle more than  years ago and with cannons pointing out over the fairways just in front.Royal Belfast Golf ClubRoyal Belfast Golf Club, only  minutes from Belfast city centre, was founded in  and is Irelandrsquos oldest golf club. It was granted royal patronage in  by Edward, Prince of Wales, the future King Edward VII. The club moved to its present location on the shores of Belfast Lough after World War I and its new -hole course was designed by Harry Colt, opening in .Holywood Golf ClubJust  miles outside of Belfast, Holywood Golf Club is where champion Rory McIlroy honed his skills as a youngster. A special area of the clubhouse is a shrine to the clubrsquos favourite son, with memorabilia including photographs of his early years playing there and replicas of the US Open and US PGA trophies. The clubhouse has been undergoing major renovation to add a new gym and indoor practice facilities. A new th green and floodlit putting green have also been created.Galgorm Castle Golf ClubNorthern Ireland Open host venue Galgorm Castle Golf Club is laid out through mature wooded grounds in the heart of the -acre Galgorm Castle Estate in Ballymena, alongside its th century castle.Check out Ireland golf for Northern Ireland golfing breaks.---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Golf at Trump TurnberryRecently voted Best Golf Resort in Europe , adding to other achievements including leading Golf Hotel of the Year, Trump Turnberry, a Luxury Collection Resort, is home to two outstanding courses and state of the art golf academy.The iconic Open Championship Ailsa course has regularly ranked number one golf course in the UK and Ireland. title: Iain Macwhirter  As May goes down for the third time  the road to Brexit just got a whole lot longer
story: The Prime Minister has behaved asshe had a thumping Commons majority when in fact she is a minority leader of an unstable coalition. Even after the Damascene conversion of arch-Brexiter Jacob Rees-Mogg, who used to described her deal as ldquovassalage, her final attempt to get a stripped-down Withdrawal Agreement through Parliament failed on Friday by a substantial majority. You have to give May full marks for her consistency: everything she touches turns to dust, even her own resignation.But thatrsquos by the by. As everyone has been saying: we are where we are. And where we are is extremely uncomfortable. Brexiters are gearing up to have a belly laugh at the opposition MPs, who will do their best throughout the coming week to find a compromise. Who do they think they are  Playing at being a provisional government  ldquoItrsquos like allowing the whelk stall to be run by the whelks, according to the Tory MP Sir Bill Cash. Butno-one  is able to run the eponymous stall, then all power to the whelks.Last weekrsquos indicative votes suggested that MPs are broadly in favour of a Brexit that keeps Britain in the EUrsquos economic loop while leaving the political institutions. Curiously, the SNP, who have been arguing for soft Brexit in two white papers and an election manesto, decided not to vote for the ious options, even the Norway model that they have long extolled. The SNP did, however, vote for the proposal from the Labour MP Margaret Beckett for a confirmatory ballot, and this option got the largest number of votes, much to everyonersquos surprise. This must be a serious possibility now that Parliament has failed to resolve the Brexit conundrum.However, this is not a Peoplersquos Vote as some have styled it. A confirmatory vote is not a rerun of the  referendum, but strictly a chance for voters to give their views on whatever deal Parliament agrees . The Kyle Wilson Amendment originally envisaged putting the Prime Ministerrsquos deal to a popular vote, assuming it was passed by Parliament. However, this confirmatory referendum might be dficult to schedule because it could collide with three other elections: a Tory leadership election, the European elections and a General Election. Brenda from Bristol will be in despair.EvenMPs fail to come up with a working compromise, they can still block a no-deal Brexit. The majority against leaving the EU without a deal is overwhelming. This means May, or her successor, will have to go cap-in-hand to Brussels in the next few days and request another, longer delay to Article . This would mean Britain participating in the European elections in May, which excites the Independent Group of Tory and Labour rebels, but is looked upon with dread by the main parties. Brussels too is worried about populist contagion spreading to other EU countries like Italy, but they are legally bound to make British participation a condition of any further extension to AVoter wrath, particularly in Labourrsquos leave constituencies, could lead to a dramatic revival of Nigel Faragersquos Ukip, or worse. The Svengali behind the  Vote Leave campaign, Dominic Cummings, is gearing up for the fight and reportedly suggesting a new party to fight for the right to leave. ldquoTell them again is the favoured slogan. The European elections might themselves turn into a kind of second referendum on Brexit.The Tories will presumably have a new leader by then, since Theresa May will surely go now there is to be the long extension she has resolutely opposed. Mind you, it is impossible to guess the Prime Ministerrsquos thought processes. She said she would goher withdrawal deal passed on Friday. But her gambit didnrsquot work. Even the opportunity to dispense with Mayrsquos services was not sufficient inducement for the Democratic Unionist Party to come on board. The joke doing the rounds last week was that she tried to fall on her sword and missed.But these things have a momentum of their own, and the Tory leadership election has already begun. Boris Johnson is the narrow frontrunner, but that could change. He might win the membership, but under Tory rules the parliamentary party has to agree the two candidates put to a postal ballot. The remainers in the Tory benches might use this as an opportunity to foil the hard Brexiters by keeping Boris off the list.Of course, what should happen when a government fails to get its most important legislation through Parliament is not a leadership election, but a General Election. The government cannot govern and, even with the Fixed-term Parliaments Act, this should lead to a General Election via a vote of no confidence. Some Conservatives might prefer to fight a General Election than European elections they had promised would never take place. But events are now out of everyonersquos control.Everyone, that is, except the EU, which now holds Britainrsquos future in the balance. Itrsquos trying not to crow about Britainrsquos abject national humiliation, but the , not the UK Parliament, will now decide the UKrsquos immediate future: deal or no deal. If MPs agree this week to back a soft Brexit involving the customs union and alignment with the single market, Brussels has promised to fast-track it in a matter of days. But the alternative, a long extension, will also suit the European Union.That means more money from Britainrsquos budget contribution, and serves as a warning to other EU countries about the dangers of trying to leave the Union. It also holds out the possibility of Britain remaining in the EU,a referendum is eventually staged.Well, that remains to be seen. What is perhaps more likely is that Britain gets stuck indefinitely in a long extension. It emerged last week that the Democratic Unionist Party, which again voted against Mayrsquos withdrawal deal, could live with a long extension. Indeed, they signalled that they could live with a customs union ndash as long as it ensured no border between Northern Ireland and the rest of the UK. The DUP may be Brexiters, but they are ardent Unionists first.A soft Brexit may now be the best way of keeping the UK together. But it should be put to the people in a confirmatory vote,for no other reason than this was not what most people thought they were voting for in . MPs have the opportunity to decide this tomorrow.How and why Theresa May failed to seek the only kind of Brexit that could get through Parliament will be left for historians to judge. One of her own Cabinet ministers, quoted on BBC Newsnight, gave the provisional verdict: ldquoShersquos the sole architect of this mess because of her inability to engage in the most basic human interaction. Who says personalities donrsquot matter in great historical events

title: dennis-kelly-on-writing-matilda-the-musical
story: ldquoFor a big musical, the show feels really theatrical, says Kelly, who wrote the show with composer and Edinburgh Festival Fringe favourite Tim Minchin. ldquoIt is polished, but it doesnrsquot always feel like it, which is great. To do the burp, we talked about loads of dferent ideas about how to do it and make it feel as though a burp had just happened, but in the end we went for something really simple, which works in big theatres, but which you could do in tiny spaces as well.The sort of spaces Kelly is talking about are exactly where the London-born writer began his play-writing career after joining a youth theatre while a teenager working in Sainsburyrsquos. His first play of note, Debris, was staged at the tiny Theatre , situated above a Battersea pub, in . He came to further prominence two years later when After The End was seen at the Traverse Theatre in Edinburgh in a production directed by Roxana Silbert for the Paines Plough Company.By , Kellyrsquos BBC Three sit-com, Pulling, co-written with Sharon Horgan, was en route to being nominated for a BAFTA, while his  stage play, Orphans, premiered at the Traverse in a Birmingham Rep production directed by Silbert. The same year saw the National Theatre of Scotland premiere Kellyrsquos play for children, Our Teacherrsquos A Troll. With such a relatively left-field back catalogue, being approached by the Royal Shakespeare Company, then led by former director of Glasgowrsquos Tron Theatre, Michael Boyd, wasnrsquot what Kelly expected to happen next.ldquoWhen the RSC came to me and said they wanted me to do a musical, I said I didnrsquot have a clue about how to do that, Kelly remembers. ldquoI think they knew my work from Debris and Our Teacherrsquos A Troll, and I wrote about three drafts and then Matthew Warchus came on board as director. They looked around exhaustively for a composer, and as soon as I spoke to Matthew about Tim Minchin, I think he knew he was the one.Minchin is the Australian-based performer, whose internationally renowned musical comedy show, Darkside, was an Edinburgh hit in , winning him what was then the Perrier Comedy Award for best newcomer. By the time Kelly and Minchinrsquos take on the story opened in Stratford in , both had been through an extensive development process.ldquoWe did four of these huge two-week workshops, Kelly remembers, ldquoand it was a lot of work. I donrsquot really like workshops, to be honest. I find that stuff hard. The first person I want to hear doing something Irsquove written is the actor playing the part, but with something this big you just have to get on with it and do it.Kelly reckons the entire process took about four years.ldquoSomeone said to me at the time that was ten per cent of my le, he says.Matilda The Musical looks set to last a lot longer than that. Following its West End transfer, the show opened on Broadway, and went on to win seven Olivier Awards ndash the most ever won by a musical ndash and five Tony Awards. It has also toured Canada and Australia prior to its current UK tour. Has such international success changed things for Kelly ldquoIn some ways it changed things, he says, ldquoand in some ways it didnrsquot. Irsquove had a show on for the last eight years, which feels strange. As a playwright you tend to have a show on, then it closes and another one goes on, so it is dferent with Matilda, but after all this time I donrsquot have a lot to do with it anymore. I donrsquot think Irsquom a lot of use to it. I used to go in and maybe give a bit of advice, but at some point yoursquove got to step back and let them get on with it.ldquoHow I wanted to work didnrsquot change. Itrsquos not like this was what I was working towards, meeting famous people and swanning round musical theatre or anything like that. I still write grimy little plays, and always have done, and writing Matilda was no dferent from writing anything  Irsquove done.Such a down to earth approach is part of Matildarsquos appeal. ldquoThere are two things I really like about it, Kelly says. ldquoThe first is Matildarsquos inability to accept the status quo, and secondly, she doesnrsquot whinge about it. A lot of the time in musicals, people say, oh,only this or that happened, I could have done this. Matilda never really does that. She just gets on with it and sorts things out. I think as well itrsquos a bit cheeky and a bit naughty as a musical. The great thing about Roald Dahl is hersquos rude, and Irsquom rude as well, and so is Tim, so it all came together because wersquore all rude. But apart from anything , itrsquos amazing seeing that little girl telling the story, and holding , people or a couple of thousand people, in the palm of their hand.Kellyrsquos forte charting the adventures of unruly small people has continued with his version of Pinocchio, which he wrote for the National Theatre in London in a production that ran in  and  directed by John Tfany, formerly of the Traverse and National Theatre of Scotland. In this way, Kelly seems naturally drawn to such fictional trouble-makers.ldquoBeing able to watch someone who is very small overpower someone who is very big, thatrsquos not a bad message, he says. ldquoI learnt very early on, kids hate things that arenrsquot fair. If you tell a kid off and yoursquore wrong, they hate it. I just love the idea that therersquos a little girl out there who gets up and sorts things out. We could probably do with a bit of that in the world just now.Matilda The Musical, The Playhouse, Edinburgh, tonight-April .www.atgtickets www.uk.matildathemusical

title: one-third-of-scots-addicted-to-social-media
story: According to a recent survey,  per cent consider themselves addicted to the online sites, while  per cent say they have a negative impact on their mental health.With the research also showing that Scots spend an average of almost eight hours a day on social media, mental health charities have called for people to take more breaks away from their computers and phones to limit the amount of time they spend on sites such as Facebook, Twitter and Youtube.Experts described the findings as ldquoconcerning and warned that high levels of social media use has been linked to depression, stress and sleep disruption.Lee Knton, director of Mental Health Foundation Scotland, said that while social media can be beneficial, it can also cause problems for some people.ldquoSocial media has dramatically changed the way we communicate and is a powerful tool for many people, she said. ldquoHowever, itrsquos concerning that these figures highlight the large amount of time people are spending each day on social media channels.ldquoResearch has shown that in some instances high levels of social media use can have a negative impact on a personrsquos mental health. Links have been shown between social media use, depression and body dysmorphia.ldquoIt can also disrupt sleep ndash which we know is extremely important for good mental health.ldquoWersquod encourage people to be aware and look out for any signs that they might be becoming affected adversely by their social media use, and seek available support.The survey, by polling firm Censuswide Scotland, revealed that  per cent of Scots feel anxiousthey cannot access their social accounts, while  per cent say they could not go  hours without visiting them.It also showed that young Scots aged - spend the most amount of time on the sites, with the age group visiting them for almost  hours each day.Mental health charity Health in Mind claimed it was important to find the ldquoright balance with social media.Alana Genge, communications manager for the charity, said: ldquoSocial media can be a great help in keeping us connected with family and friends but we also know that it can sometimes be a drain on our emotional wellbeing.ldquoItrsquos healthy to take a break from social media ndash it allows you to take time out to enjoy your surroundings and is an opportunity to reduce stress.ldquoIf you feel that social media is having a negative impact on your wellbeing then consider ways of reducing the time you spend on it.ldquoYou could set yourself a cut off time, turn off your notications or make an agreement with yourself that you will only check your social media accounts a couple of times a day.ldquoYou need to find what works for you and then evaluate whether the changes you have made have resulted in a positive impact on your wellbeing.The Censuswide survey, which polled more than  people in Scotland, revealed that almost half of those asked believe the Scottish Government should do more to help combat social media addiction.More than two-thirds also said they want age restrictions on social media to be increased to -years-old.Commenting on the survey, Jordan Ferguson, from Censuswide Scotland said: ldquoThe Censuswide Scotland Online Behaviours Report looked at the online habits of a sample of the Scottish population.ldquoThe research reveals some interesting trends and a clear concerns from Scots about the impact these s are having on their mental health.

title: that-sinking-feeling-peat-bogs-are-restored-across-old-coalfields
story: Scientists are celebrating after restoring more than  hectares ofpeat bog across the old coalfields onthe hillsides above pit villages such as Auchinleck and Mauchline.Their work is part of a nationwide programme of peatland restoration,a critical effort to recreate the boggy carbon sinks that once made up muchof Scotland.The Scottish Government has just announced another pound.million in funding for such efforts as it seeks to regenerate some , hectaresof peat bog by . Four-fths of Scotlandrsquos peatlands are now listedas damaged.An army of expert contractors and volunteers from East Ayrshire Coalfield Environment Initiativecreated or repaired the  hectares of peatland, including  within the Muirkirk Uplands Site of Special Scientic Interest.CEI manager Daisy Whytock said: ldquoPeatlands make up one-fth of the land cover in East Ayrshire, and much of this area has been degraded in some way.ldquoThe peatland restoration work carried out by the CEI, its partners and local land owners has the potential to benefit bioersity, the environment and local people.The work at Muirkirk was carriedout over winter with the help of Sorn Estates, which will farm the moors.Between December  and February , specialist peatland restoration contractors installed more than , dams and water-retaining bunds across a dense network of old ditches to re-wet the degraded peatland.Peat-forming Sphagnum mosses and bog plants can now grow in the blocked ditches and will slowly seal them with new peat.This work will help reduce greenhouse gas emissions, improve local water quality and protect habitat for rare species such as hen harriers, curlew and Large Heath butterflies.A healthy bog acts like a sponge, capturing rainwater during storms and slowly releasing the filtered water into local river catchments throughoutthe year.On drained peatlands rain water pours into ditches and watercourses carrying eroded dry peat. This contaminates water courses and increases the risk of flooding. By blocking drainage ditches, local rivers and communities will benefit from improved water quality.These special wetlands are home to many rare plants and animals that are specially adapted to the soggy conditions. Draining the bog makes it harder for these wet-loving species to survive and prevents the formation of new peat.Peat is formed from partially-decomposed plant material that accumulates in the wet, acidic conditions. As they grow, peatland plants trap carbon from the atmosphere that is then stored as peat below the bogrsquos living surface.Drained peatlands release vast amounts of carbon back into the atmosphere. It is estimated degraded peatlands contribute . per cent of global, man-made CO emissions. The peat soils at Sorn Estate are more than ft  metres deep in some places and the work carried out by CEI will help keep the peat locked away. A wet surface covered in bog mosses will also capture more carbon from the atmosphere, helping to combat climate change.More than % of Scotlandrsquos land area is covered in peaty soils. Largeareas have been damaged over centuries, with extensive damage to the core peat reserves and its specialised vegetation.Scottish Natural Heritagersquos Peatland Action said Scotland losing the carbon stored in our peat soils would be the equivalent of more than  times Scotlandrsquos annual greenhouse gas emissions. So far , hectares has been saved.UK authorities have previously said they wanted to phase out peat compost for amateur gardeners by next year.

title: labour-accused-of-hypocrisy-over-big-oil-ahead-of-climate-vote
story: MSPs will today vote on the principles of a Bill putting new carbon reduction targets into law.Labour last night said it wanted to ldquoembolden the legislation, by setting a target of zero greenhouse gas emissions by , instead of the  per cent cut proposed by the SNP.However, it also emerged yesterday that a Labour MSP will be promoting the North Sea oil industry in an exhibition next to the Parliamentrsquos debating chamber this week.Lewis Macdonald, a list MSP for North East Scotland, has sponsored a large display and information stall for Oil  Gas UK, the trade body representing the offshore industry.MSPs will walk past it on their way to vote for climate change targets.The Scottish Greens said Labour was two-faced and could not be trusted on the issue.Friends of the Earth Scotland said it was ldquosadly symptomatic of MSPs talking tough on climate change while backing the fuels that cause it.The environmental campaign also said it was disappointing that it couldnrsquot organise a lobbying event inside Holyrood about the Bill, but the industry was allowed in.ldquoThis risks reinforcing the misconceptions of some MSPs that oil and gas is somehow nothing to do with climate change, it said.Scottish Green MSP Mark Ruskell said: ldquoLast week, Scottish Labour voted down our proposition to declare a climate emergency. This week, as parliament debates the climate change bill, theyrsquove invited the oil and gas industry to lobby MSPs right outside the chamber.ldquoItrsquos clear that on climate policy, like many other issues, Labour is at war with itself and canrsquot be trusted.Dr Richard Dixon, FoE Scotland Director, said: ldquoThis is sadly symptomatic of the many MSPs who apparently see no contradiction between supporting the expansion of oil and gas extraction and action on climate change. The extraction and burning of fossil fuels is the key driver of climate change.ldquoSNP, Labour, Conservative and Liberal Democrats all refused to condemn the industry-led policy of lsquoMaximising Economic Recoveryrsquo of North Sea oil and gas in last weekrsquos Climate Emergency debate, which means maximising the damage to our climate.ldquoWe must cut our use of oil and gas - we need to stop going after new sources and plan an orderly but rapid transition to a green economy.A recent YouGov poll found % of people in Scotland were concerned about climate change.The most common reasons were concern for future generations , threat to wildle , natural disasters , and rising sea levels Scotlandrsquos greenhouse gas output has fallen by % since .With scientists warning of runaway temperatures without urgent action, the new Climate Change Bill would set a % reduction target for  , with an interim cut of % by  , followed by % in  and % in .Critics say it is not enough.Stop Climate Chaos Scotland, which is due to stage a rally outside Holyrood today, said greater urgency was needed in the next decade.Chair Tom Ballantine said: ldquoClimate change is the most urgent and pressing crisis facing the world, and Scotlandrsquos targets for cutting emissions must reflect our commitment to meeting that challenge.ldquoThe increasing frequency and severity of climate disasters around the world show that we are running out of time to solve this crisis.ldquoAs it stands, this Bill is out of step with what climate science says is needed. In recent months wersquove witnessed an upsurge in climate activism and public concern, including thousands of school children going on strike to demand more action from Government. Over , people gave their views that this Bill needed to be stronger, but they have been ignored by the Government. ldquoLabour environment spokesperson Claudia Beamish said: ldquoLabour will seek to amend the SNPrsquos Climate Change Bill to introduce a bold and ambitious target of net zero emissions by  at the latest and bolder interim targets. The Bill as it stands simply does not meet the challenges of the global emergency of climate change.ldquoWe can meet targets fairly [with] a Just Transition Commission to ensure well paid jobs as we sht towards the net zero economy and society.ldquoScotland deserves itrsquos very own Green New Deal bringing new well paid jobs - and a legal ban on fracking. This is the future of our planet, the water we drink and the air we breathe. We have a duty to our children, grandchildren and the global south to tackle climate change now ndash and we will make sure this Bill delivers fairly on climate and intergenerational justice.Mr Ruskell added: ldquoWe have just over a decade to take the bold action that is requiredwe want to avert the worst impacts of the climate crisis. The bill as it is written does not go nearly far enough in addressing this.ldquoMinisters need to set a target to reduce carbon emissions to net zero by  at the latest.ldquoIt is simply not good enough for Ministers to use the rhetoric of lsquoclimate leadersrsquo while failing to take the necessary action to back that up.Reacting to the criticism of the fossil fuel exhibition, Scottish Labour said: ldquoLabour supports a just transition to the net zero economy and society in a way that meets robust targets while protecting jobs.ldquoItrsquos disappointing to see the Greens attack us on this when they should be focussed on emboldening a timid Climate Change Bill.

title: screen-children-early-for-psychopathic-traits-says-carstairs-expert
story: Dr John Marshall, head of forensic clinical psychology services at The State Hospitals board for Scotland, said certain behavioural traits can be found in children as young as five.These can include not responding to parents or boundaries, poor or sadistic treatment of other children or animals, showing independence and not being expressive or showing emotion.Read more: From Shipman to Bodkin Adams - serial killing medics in the spotlight in EdinburghThe teenager snatched Alesha from her bed as she slept at her grandparents home on the Isle of Bute and finally admitted his crime in a psychological report prepared ahead of his sentencing in March.Writing in The Scotsman, Dr Marshall said: "You dont become a psychopath on your th birthday."Psychopathic traits start in very early childhood, have predictable pathways and yet we do not assess children for this neurodevelopmental problem."At the age of , such traits are already entrenched and chronic so it is time for policy to catch up with research, given the enormous social costs of psychopathy."We have to deal with psychopathy trajectories in childhood head-on now to ert budding psychopaths and make sure what happened to poor Alesha never happens again."Read more: Inside the mind of Karen Buckleys killer - a psychopath and budding serial killerHe added early identication can be the focal point and made a number of suggestions on how to solve what he called a "major public health issue".Dr Marshall also pointed out Campbell had not suffered childhood trauma, meaning it was not a factor in the murder of his young victim.Lord Matthews, sentencing Campbell at the High Court in Glasgow last month, said social work and psychologist reports "had painted a clear picture of a cold, callous, calculating, remorseless and dangerous inidual".Read more: Donald Trump outscores Adolf Hitler on psychopathic traits testHe said the teenager had shown a "staggering lack of remorse" and told him: "Not once did I detect a flicker of emotion from you".In the psychologists report, Campbell also described his reaction to seeing Alesha as "a moment of opportunity".

title: brexit-tearing-democracy-apart-as-4m-people-face-losing-right-to-vote-in-local-elections-with-no-deal
story: The UK Government has confirmed that almost half a million Britons living in the EU and another .m EU citizens living in the UK would be unable to cast a vote in future council elections.Tom Brake, the Lib Demsrsquo Brexit spokesman revealed the information through a parliamentary question on reciprocal voting rights, which have only been secured with Spain, leaving millions more potentially unable to vote next month.In a written parliamentary response, Robin Walker, the Brexit Minister, said: "The UK pushed for reciprocal rights to stand and vote in local elections in negotiations on citizens rights but they will not form part of the Withdrawal Agreement."Instead we are pursuing bilateral agreements with inidual member states where possible to apply in a deal or no-deal scenario.He added: ldquoWe are pleased to have secured the first such bilateral agreement on local voting rights with Spain in January and we are continuing our discussions with other member states."Mr Brake said the ministerrsquos response showed how Brexit was "tearing democracy apart" due to "callous Conservative Party self-interest".He explained: "Far from illusions that Brexit would renew our democracy, it is instead tearing it apart and stripping people of their rights all because of Tory incompetence.The London MP stressed that many EU citizens filled vital roles in the health service, schools and across Parliament. ldquoThey deserve better and the Liberal Democrats demand better, he declared.Campaigners for EU citizens in the UK, themillion, said the potential loss of rights in May came on top of EU citizens being left without a vote in the  referendum.Ilse Mogensen, public affairs and campaigns officer for themillion, said: "EU citizens living in the UK were denied a vote on our own future in the  referendum."To add insult to injury, we now face the loss of our right to vote and stand as candidates in local elections.She added: "The Welsh and Scottish Governments have confirmed that EU citizens will keep the right to vote the UK Government should do the same instead of leaving the democratic rights of .m people in limbo."

title: 4m low carbon project for firm
story: A north east firm is installing a new refrigeration system set to be one of the most sophisticated in Europe.Mackie’s of Scotland will replace its existing freezing equipment with low carbon, power efficient units run on ammonia - a natural refrigerant gas that poses no threat to the environment.The £million project is being carried out at the firm’s Westertown Farm near Rothienorman.The innovative combined solution will cool Mackie’s ice cream with heat from a biomass boiler, powered by a sustainable energy source.The £ million project is being brought to le thanks to a grant from the Scottish Government Government’s Low Carbon Infrastructure Transition Programme, match funded by Mackie’s through a loan from Bank of Scotland.The investment will be open as a demonstrator project in the hope that its success will inspire other Scottish fish, meat and dairy food manufacturers to adopt similar energy-efficient technology.Commenting Gerry Stephens, Finance Director at Mackie’s of Scotland, said: “Our ultimate aim is to one day go completely off-grid and use % renewable energy. This is an important step towards realising these green ambitions.“We’re very excited about this project as, the technologies involved are tried-and-tested methods but have not been commonly combined to produce a low-carbon, low-energy solution for cold store refrigeration.“With Bank of Scotland’s support we are realising our green ambitions and, in the long run, we hope that our new system will set a precedent and make the energy-intensive food and drink sector more sustainable.”data-src"https:images-o.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"Ashley Armstrong, Gary Tolometti and Mrs Henderson with some of The Hairy Bikers and their new safety equipment"  Safety equipment boost for cycle club viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "INVE | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "INVE | Article Teaser"

title: campaigner says kintore station must open as soon as possible
story: A local councillor who has played a leading role in the campaign for a Kintore station has said it must be completed as soon as possible and opened with the minimum delay.A delay in the expected opening date for the new station was announced in mid-March when Aberdeenshire Councils Infrastructure Services Committee received a briefing from Network Rail on the current railway works between Aberdeen and Inverurie.Commenting East Garioch cllr Martin Ford said: "I am surprised and disappointed that Transport Scotland is now indicating May  as their date for opening the new Kintore station. A planned opening date of December  has been in the public domain for many years without the rail industry expressing any alternative view."The dates of December  and May  are signicant because these are the points in the year when new rail timetables are introduced.Representatives of Network Rail attended a meeting of Kintore Community Council last week where the delay to the expected station opening date was not well received. Cllr Martin Ford was present at the meeting along with other Aberdeenshire councillors and community councillors.Cllr Ford added: "What I still want to see is Kintore station included in the December  rail timetable. If it isnt, the station cant open until the start of the next timetable in May  – evenall the building work is finished well before that."So put Kintore station in the December  timetable but with a note against it: Station under construction and expected to open during the currency of this timetable – see local announcements. That has been done where to allow new stations to be opened as soon as they are ready on completion of construction work."Its then up to Transport Scotland, Network Rail and the contractors to get the station finished as quickly as they can, so it can open as soon as possible, albeit after December  but before May ."It is believed that since Cllr Ford asked that Kintore station still be included in the December  timetable, Aberdeenshire Council transportation officers have made a similar request."We need Kintore station open and available for residents to use at the earliest possible date," said Cllr Ford.data-src"https:images-o.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"Gordon MP Colin Clark with Allyn Harper and Bryan Harper"  MP visits Insch firm viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "INVE | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "INVE | Article Teaser"

title: charity dog walk at haddo
story: The Great British Dog Walk is back for a fth year and is coming to Haddo House  Country Park on Saturday, April .Hundreds of walkers of all ages, and dogs of all shapes and sizes, will be ‘walking the walk’ to have fun, meet like-minded people and support Hearing Dogs for Deaf People.There are two route optionsmaking it ideal for dog owners, families, single walkers, organised walking groups and those who simply want to meet lots of dogs and get a bit of exercise for a good cause.Gill Yeates, National Fundraising Manager at Hearing Dogs, said: “Hearing dogs are real le-changers. Not only do they alert deaf people to important sounds, like the smoke alarm, intruder alarm and alarm clock, but they also provide constant emotional support, helping people to feel less isolated and enabling them to overcome barriers and reconnect with their communities.”There is a free limited-edition Great British Dog Walk dog bandana for each adult ticket purchased for the walk and working hearing dogs will be available to meet on the day.To sign-up or for more informationabout the event visit www.greatbritishdogwalk.org.Tickets are £ in advance or £ on the day.The Great British Dog Walk at Haddo starts at am. title: safety equipment boost for cycle club
story: A girls cycle club at Kellands School in Inverurie has purchased new safety equipment to thanks to a kind donation.The Garioch and North Marr Community Safety Group recently presented the school’s Hairy Bikers cycle club with £.The money was put to good use and enabled the club to purchase rechargable helmet lights and reflective gloves to allow them to keep cycling all year round and into the darker nights.This is the second donation that the clubhas received from the safety group.The first donation was used to purchase reflective jackets for the club’s members.Gary Tolometti of the Garioch and North Marr Community Safety Group went along to the school on Friday, March  to see the new equipment.Speaking to the Herald Ashley Armstrong, I Bike Officer for Aberdeenshire, said: “This donation has given the girls more opportunities to get out in the darker nights and they are always keen to get out as much as possible.“Last year we wanted to get out later on but had to stop andto school as it was getting too dark and unsafe for the girls.“The jackets we purchased earlier are very useful and the girls have used them well.”She added: “The girls are keen to head out mountain biking so hopefully we will now get the chance to do this later on.Commenting on the donation Gary said: “The dference that these items will make to the girls is great.“We are really happy that the donation will help to let them get out and stay out longer.“It’s also good to see the kids active and getting outdoors.”data-src"https:images-o.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! title: have your say on local development plan
story: Aberdeenshire residents are being invited to submit their views to a consultation which will help shape the future of planning in the area.Anyone with an interest in local planning policy and land allocation for development is encouraged to take part before Monday, April .A Local Development Plansets out the policies that will be used for assessing planning applications and identies development opportunities in an area.The Aberdeenshire Local Development Plan  is currently being prepared and as part of that process, planners have produced a Main Issues Report .It is a document designed to create debate and comment, discussing all the bids received for development on sites across the area.Prepared by planners after initial discussions with communities and councillors, it outlines what needs to change in the current  LDP, and sets out preferred options alongside reasonable alternatives.This includes changes to the policies used to determine planning applications as well as additional land allocated for development.An invitation was issued early last year to the development industry and landowners to advise Aberdeenshire Council of which sites they think should be in the LDP, and why.It is not expected there will be signicant additional allocations of land in the next plan, although some sites in the existing plan that haven’t been developed could be title: who do you want to be the next prime minister take part in our poll
story: As Brexit shudders to a halt with parliament failing to back Mrs Mays withdrawal agreement and failing to choose an alternative to her deal, twice, a no deal Brexit and a general election are becoming more likely by the day.
