title: hundreds visitors expected 2019 north west angling
story: The biggest event on the local angling calendar looks set to attract hundreds of visitors this weekend when the North West Angling Fair is hosted in and around the spectacular setting of Castlederg Castle.The family friendly event hosted by Derry City and Strabane District Council is free admission and is set to bring together a host of the UK and Ireland’s top fly dressers, casters and top angling specialists.The fair will be open from am – pm each day of Saturday  and Sunday April  and will feature appearances and demonstrations as well as interactive opportunities for the public to get involved.The fair will host stalls from retailers and fly tying demonstrations while outside on the Derg River some of the best casters in the world will impart their wisdom through demonstrations.A special youth element entitled CATCHwill be hosted by the Loughs Agency where experienced and professional coaches will be on-hand to train new, novice and experienced young anglers in game, coarse and sea angling.Looking ahead to the event, Mayor of Derry City and Strabane District Council, Councillor John Boyle, encouraged local people to take advantage of the world class event on their doorstep and noted that it will attract thousands of visitors to the Council area.“I’d like to congratulate the Festival and Events team at Council for assembling a stellar line-up of special guests and an exciting programme of activities for the  North West Angling Fair,” he said.“This is the first time the fair has come to Castlederg which will allow us to showcase our angling offering not only to visitors to our Council area but also to local people who may be considering taking up fishing as a hobby.“The programme is family orientated and allows people of all ages to get involved and learn more about the art of angling and I’d encourage as many people as possible to come along and sample what it has to offer.”googletag.cmd.push .addSize.addSize.buildslot  googletag.defineSlot.defineSizeMapping.setTargeting.setTargeting.setTargeting.addServicegoogletag.displaygoogletag.pubads.refreshFestival and Events Manager at Derry City and Strabane District Council, Jacqueline Whoriskey, noted the Fair has something to suit all levels and tastes.“We are delighted to once again host the North West Angling Fair and bring it to the spectacular surroundings of Castlederg Castle, using the grounds of the St Eugene’s GAC and the Derg River,” she said. “Some of the biggest names in the angling world will be in attendance and there is a wide range of activities and demonstrations to choose from.“The event is free of charge but people can buy the best equipment and supplies for their fishing needs at the trade stands.“We are particularly excited about the CATCH Hub, hosted by the Loughs Agency, that will help inspire the next generation of anglers through short workshops covering casting, netting, fish identication, rover invertebrates, bait, lures, fly tying and safety and enable participants to achieve the CAST Angling Starter certicate.”Among the high calibre lineup in attendance at the fair will be well-known multiple world fly casting champions Hywel Morgan who will be demonstrating angling techniques and giving expert advice along with the likes of Robert Gillespie, Michael O’Kane and Stevie Munn.The exhibition area will offer the public the chance to browse and shop around for equipment from a wide range of local traders including Rodgers Fishing Tackle, The Bridge Gun and Tackle, River Mourne Gun and Tackle and The Great Outdoors.The ever popular Fly Tyers Row area will afford visitors the opportunity to watch fly dressers practice their craft and will include demonstrations from acclaimed tier Arthur Greenwood and local youngster Laoi Coyle.The full lineup for the North West Angling Fair is available at www.derrystrabane anglingfair.CAPTION:Local anglers get personal instruction from three times World Spey Casting Champion Gordon Armstrong from Inverness, Scotland demonstrating his skills on the River Mourne at Strabane during the NW Angling Fair last year.

title: Autism friendly swimming sessions in Downpatrick
story: FAMILIES with autistic children will soon enjoy a dedicated swim session at Down Leisure Centre.A -week trial where families can use the pool at the new Market Street centre on Sundays from -pm is expected to start on April .More than  families in the Downpatrick area alone will be able to avail of the facility for the first time.Children with autism can often feel overwhelmed in new and noisy environments which a general public swim session would represent.It is intended that several initiatives such as lowering the light level will be trialled over the coming weeks to see what provides the best environment for swimmers.Newry, Mourne and Down District Councilrsquos Active and Healthy Communities Committee passed a proposal on Thursday evening to give the sessions the green light.Slieve Croob councillor Roisin Howell proposed the pilot scheme which was seconded by Slieve Gullion councillor Kate Loughran.However, it needs to be formally approved by the full council at its monthly meeting next Monday night.The pilot means that the pool will be closed to the general public from .pm for  weeks until June .While it is considered only as a pilot scheme, it is hoped by councillors, officials and local parents that an exclusive swim session for children with autism can be made permanent.Newry Leisure Centre has provided an exclusive weekly swim session for families with autistic children since it opened in .Cllr Howell said: ldquoThis will ensure the pool is accessible to people with autism who may find peak times a challenge. It is vital our leisure services are made welcoming for our entire community.Council chairman Mark Murnin welcomed the move and said he was delighted that families with children with autism could enjoy the same facilities as families in Newry.Committee chairman Cllr Gareth Sharvin said he had raised the matter with the February meeting.The move was also welcomed by Rowallane councillors Billy Walker and Terry Andrews.The news has been welcomed by Downpatrick Autism Family Support Group which has been working with the council on the proposal.Group chair Aacuteine Sloan welcomed the move, saying ldquoit will now make this first class facility accessible to all.She added: ldquoIt will give local autism families the opportunity to use the pool and feel more relaxed alongside other families that understand the struggles that may arise. I hope this is something that continues after the trail period.ldquoWe are also hopeful that the council will source fully qualied special needs swimming instructors soon too so our children can have the same opportunities as their peers..prettyPhoto

title: Ballygowan business gains contract with leading aircraft firm
story: AIRCRAFT manufacturer Dornier Seawings has contracted Ballygowan precision engineering company McGreevy Engineering to machine parts for its iconic Seastar amphibious aircraft,.Dornier rose to prominence in the s and s as a manufacturer of large, all metal flying boats.The Seastar, designed in Germany, is engineered to operate from runway and water surfaces allowing for short field take-off and landing capabilities.Representatives from the local company met initially with Dornier Seawings at the Farnborough Airshow last July and subsequently gained a number of contracts.The Ballygowan firmrsquos managing director, Aaron McGreevy, said it was very pleased to be working with Dornier Seawings, a multicultural and multi-national joint venture between the Dornier family and two fully state-owned Chinese enterprises.ldquoGiven our recent investment to ersy our capabilities this is great news indeed, said Mr McGreevy.ldquoThe Dornier brand has a heritage of a pioneering spirit. Like many Northern Ireland companies it is built on the rich experience of engineering expertise, in this case, in aviation.ldquoThe Dornier family is highly respected given their  years of aircraft production and we hope to continue to build on this relationship given our many years of experience in engineering.The Seastar is a multi-purpose aircraft covering a wide operational range of VIP transport, commercial, government special and corporate missions.Paul Larkin of Dornier Seawings said the company was delighted to be working with McGreevy Engineering.ldquoThe Seastar is superior in every important measure ndash speed, range, safety, cabin size and lower maintenance costs. It is designed in Germany and strictly adheres to Dornierrsquos high quality standards, he explained.ldquoIt is therefore signicant that we partner with like-minded companies that understand our ethos, requirement for quality and on time delivery needs as well as added value.McGreevy Engineering will be exhibiting at next weekrsquos annual Aircraft Interiors Expo, AIX , in Hamburg..prettyPhoto

title: Ballynahinch find way past Old Belvedere
story: BALLYNAHINCH were shorn of seven front liners by the Ulster A participation in the CARA cup in Boston.Consequently, they were rated by many as underdogs going in to this crucial home fixture against an Old Belvedere outfit coming into good late season form and with former contracted star Steve Crosbie pulling the strings expertly at out-half.However, the locals had good reason to believe in themselves as a similar side came away from Dublin with a superb win against the same opponents in the reverse fixture early in the season.Ben Cullen and Conor Piper earned well-deserved starts in the front row with Ollie Loughead making a timelyfrom injury to take his place at openside while Ryan Wilson slotted in to the out-half jersey and Richard Reaney came back into the team on the right wing.Ballynahinch were also able to call on the services of evergreen prop forward Jerry Cronin, who stepped up as front row cover.Playing into the breeze in the first half, Ballynahinch started well and took the lead with a Ross Adair try on  minutes which was converted by Reaney.The next  minutes were all Belvo as they scored two tries to lead - on the half time whistle.However, Adair popped up with another smart finish and Reaney did the rest to give Hinch the lead as the teams turned roundLoughead had already been lost to injury at this stage with the versatile Connor Phillips his replacement.The try on half time proved crucial in the context of the match as Hinch pulled clear early in the second half when a fine spell of driving play from the forwards took them close to the posts.Adair snfed his hat-trick and when the ball was recycled he was on hand to step inside the cover smartly for another converted try.However, Old Belvedere came charging back immediately with an excellent score. A Rhys OrsquoDonnell box kick was marginally long and carried back with interest before quick hands from Crosbie put his winger in for a superb try.The conversion left the game in the balance at -.The home side continued to dominate possession and territory and a Reaney penalty following a great breakdown turnover from skipper Aaron Cairns gave them a little breathing space.Old Belvedere, despite showing admirable invention, were guilty on occasion of overplaying and a series of errors meant they were pinned back in their own half.The bonus point score went to Cronin who drove over the line when Adair was held up just short and with  minutes to go Hinch looked certain of victory at -.A superb defensive effort then kept their Dublin opponents at bay in relative comfort until the th minute when the pressure eventually led to an overlap to leave the away side in with a chance of a draw as the game reached its final moments.However, in their desperation to run the ball out of defence and keep the game alive, Old Belvedere conceded a penalty which Reaney knocked over to clinch the win.That should have been the end of proceedings, but a penalty from a scrum led to another Belvo charge and they were awarded another penalty which Crosbie slotted with the last kick of the game to take two points back to Dublin.Ballynahinch continue their winning run and stand level with Old Wesley at the top of the table with two games to go.Ballynahinch Old Belvedere AIL DIVISION B.prettyPhoto

title: Best friends laid to rest after accident
story: BEST friends Shane McAnallen and Martin Patterson were buried side by side on Saturday.The two men in their twenties died together in a car crash on the Carlingford to Omeath Road in the early hours of Monday, March .It is believed they died at the scene and that no other vehicle was involved.Mr McAnallen was from the Castlewellan area and Mr Patterson was from Bryansford.Their tragic deaths, and that of missing Newcastle woman Ruth Maguire who also died in Carlingford over the St Patrickrsquos holiday weekend, left the community numb with grief.A community candlelight vigil was held in Carlingford on Sunday night which was attended by representatives from the deceasedrsquos families and rescue and emergency services.All three were connected to Bryansford GAC mdash the young men were former under-age players while mother of three Ms Maguire was the clubrsquos under-age coach.Mr Patterson also played for a time with Ballynahinch RFC U-s.He and Ms Maguire were also connected to St Maryrsquos Primary School in Newcastle.Ms Maguirersquos children attend the school and she was active in the St Maryrsquos Parent Support Group while Mr Patterson was a fondly remembered past pupil of the school.Ms Maguire was also known through her work as a casual leisure attendant at Newcastle Centre and also as a nursing assistant at Daisy Hill Hospital in Newry.The  year-old had been reported missing from a group of friends on a hen night while there were out socialising in Carlingford on Saturday.An extensive land and sea search was carried out on Sunday.On Monday, her body was recovered from the lough around the same time as the deaths of the young men became public.Mr McAnallen and Mr Patterson, also known as Marty Patt to friends, were laid to rest in separate ceremonies with many local people attending both services.A funeral for Mr McAnallen was held in St Malachyrsquos Church in Castlewellan early on Saturday morning. He was laid to rest in St Patrickrsquos Cemetery in Bryansford where his friend was to join him within hours.Officiating at his Requiem Mass, Father Denis McKinlay later said that he spoke of the great sorrow as no-one expects to bury such young people.ldquoItrsquos an incredibly sad time as these were two popular and much-loved young men, he said later.Mr McAnallen is survived by his parents, Michael and Bernie, and by his siblings Michaela and Laura.A service for Mr Patterson was held later in St Patrickrsquos Church in Bryansford.Mr Patterson had recently started to work with Downpatrick groundworks firm, CP Flanagan Contracts.His employer, Mr Paul Flanagan, described him as a ldquogood, straightforward lad.He is survived by his parents, Colin and Angela, siblings James and Danielle, and grandparents Jim and Joy Brown and Kathleen Patterson.His family asked for donations in lieu of flowers to be given to the charity that Mr Patterson had volunteered for, Exodus Romanian Project..prettyPhoto

title: Calls for financial aid for Air Ambulance NI
story: POLITICIANS at the provincersquos local councils are being encouraged to provide financial support for the Air Ambulance Northern Ireland.The appeal has been issued by Rowallane councillor Billy Walker, who last month secured across-the-board political support from his Newry, Mourne and Down Council colleagues to provide funding to the service which plays a critical role across the district.It has been revealed that between August  and November last year, the air ambulance responded to  incidents across the council area.ldquoThe air ambulance is vital for people across the district, given its rural nature and attractions like the Mournes and Strangford Lough, Cllr Walke rsaid.The Rowallane politician recently visited the air ambulancersquos base outside Lisburn where he was joined by two of his party colleagues from Mid Ulster and Derry and Strabane Councils, both of which have agreed to provide financial support for the lesaving service.With three local authorities already on board, Cllr Walker hopes that the remaining eight Northern Ireland councils will provide financial support.He said while Stormont funds the air ambulance crew, medicines and medical equipment, it should be picking up the remainder of the servicersquos running costs.He confirmed that Strangford MP Jim Shannon plans to raise this issue with Department of Health Permanent Secretary, Richard Pengelly.ldquoDown District is already a main user of the air ambulance service which has already helped save a number of lives, Cllr Walker continued.ldquoThe service relies heavily upon donations to help meet the servicersquos poundm annual running costs and while this is welcome, I believe local councils and indeed the Department of Health needs to do more.Cllr Walker says while the air ambulance relies heavily upon public support, it also needs a sustainable funding stream to ensure it can continue to save lives and hopes this will be provided by the Department of Health.ldquoThe service is a key component of the emergency services and should not have to rely on charitable donations, he continued.ldquoGiven the costs to keep the service in the air, I believe all of the Provincersquos  councils, supported by the government department, have a role to play.Cllr Walker, who was recently made aware of the excellent work of the air ambulance when the crew responded to an emergency in Killyleagh when a woman was involved in an accident in Plantation Street, confirmed that Newry, Mourne and Down Councilrsquos financial contribution to the service will be agreed at a meeting of its efficiencies working group.He added: ldquoThe air ambulance is an excellent service which all of Northern Ireland is fortunate to have and it is important that we continue to support its work..prettyPhoto

title: Campaign group calls for meeting over lighthouse
story: THE campaign group battling to save the iconic sweeping beam at St Johnrsquos Point Lighthouse near Killough is seeking a meeting with local politicians.The Lecale Lightkeepers want to meet face-to-face with Newry, Mourne and Down councillors to spell out why the beam must be retained and why the proposed LED replacement suggested by the Dublin-based Commissioner of Irish Lights is totally inadequate and unacceptable.Campaigners have also submitted a Freedom of Information request to the local authority for copies of all correspondence between the councilrsquos Enterprise, Regeneration and Tourism Department and the Commissionerrsquos office on the lighthouse issue.Last month, the local authority was heavily criticised for excluding the press and public from a meeting mdash billed as a workshop mdash involving councillors and representatives from the Commissionerrsquos office, including its most senior official, Captain Robert McCabe.The council subsequently confirmed the workshop, held at the local authorityrsquos headquarters in Downpatrick, was a ldquopreliminary information session for councillors and that prior to any plans being finalised or put in place for the future of the lighthouse, a wide ranging public consultation would take place.The workshop lasted well over one hour but the report from the behind-closed-doors session which has been sent to councillors amounts to a paltry two and a half lines.Signicantly, the paper does not detail the questions put by councillors or, most importantly the response from Commissioner officials, compounding the frustration of those seeking to retain the beam.They are angry that the council report provides no detail whatsoever of what was discussed and simply states the issue of the lighthouse beam will be raised at district electoral forums across the district.Campaigners insist that as the Commissioner of Irish Lights had the opportunity to put its case before councillors, it is only right and proper and in keeping with equality legislation and good old fashioned fairness, that the Lecale Lightkeepers should be afforded the same opportunity.The campaigners have been exchanging correspondence with council officials and described one response confirming the sweeping beam issue will be discussed at ious district electoral forums with a view to having a joint meeting with Captain McCabe, which the public could also attend, as ldquodismissive and derogatory.The Lecale Lightkeepers have also vehemently rejected the councilrsquos view that a joint DEA meeting to put questions directly to representatives of the Commissioners of Irish Lights would be the ldquomost appropriate forum to address the issues they have raised.A spokesperson for the campaign group said councillors were keen to protect the iconic, sweeping beam, describing plans to remove the mercury bearing which rotates the Fresnel lamp due to health concerns as ldquoflimsy and flawed.They have also rejected claims that a new LED light proposed by the Commissioners would be the same, arguing this ldquosimply isnrsquot true.Campaigners say it is their understanding that some councillors are at a complete loss as to why the local authority is denying them a chance to meet all of the councilrsquos  members to state their case.They say Commissioners were in Downpatrick last month because councillors voted unanimously to invite them for a meeting to discuss the controversial plan to replace the sweeping beam with what, in their view, is a much inferior light.ldquoThe irony of what is happening is not lost on us, said the spokesperson for the campaign group.ldquoCouncillors discuss the issue of the sweeping beam and unanimously agree that it should be retained. They propose to meet with the Commissioners which happens but yet when campaigners ask to meet with all the districtrsquos elected representatives at one time, we are denied this opportunity. Why The spokesperson added: ldquoWe hope councillors will demand a detailed account of the recent workshop so the views of the Commissioners can be critically examined and scrutinised by not only campaigners, but elected representatives, to determinethey are accurate.ldquoIf, in our opinion they are not, we should be given an opportunity to refute them in front of councillors who were elected to represent the people of this district and who are accountable to them.ldquoIf changes are made at St Johnrsquos Point Lighthouse, the historic character of the sweeping beam will be lost forever. We must all stand together and ensure this does not happen. What is being offered by the Commissioner is inferior to what we currently have.A council spokesman said officers from the the Commissioner of Irish Lights will be invited to future meetings of the districtrsquos respective DEA Forums.He explained this is to ensure that information can be shared and that local stakeholders and communities are fully consulted upon any proposals for St Johnrsquos Lighthouse in the immediate future before any plans are finalised.The spokesman added: ldquoRequests for details of future public consultations on plans for St Johnrsquos Point Lighthouse would be best addressed by the Commissioner of Irish Lights..prettyPhoto

title: Crossgar food sauce firm in deal with Aldi
story: PREP House Sauces in Crossgar has won its first business with discount retailer Aldi in the Republic of Ireland.Prep House is a family business which has won a string of national awards for its original sauces and dressings.Itrsquos now supplying its pepper sauce to Aldi for its network of  stores across the Republic.Managing director Paul Bell, who took over the management reins of the company in , described the new deal as ldquoa marvellous boost.ldquoThis very important business for us resulted when we swtly followed up a lead from Invest NIrsquos Drew McIvor, he added.ldquoOur approach was well received by the Aldi buyer who was extremely interested and very supportive. We were subsequently invited to pitch several products including the pepper sauce that is now on Aldirsquos shelves. Working with Aldi is a tremendous experience.ldquoAs a result of the outstanding taste of the product and the convenient two-serve sachet, wersquove been invited to create additional sauces for the chain.The Aldi listing is Prep Housersquos biggest deal to date in the Republic and its most signicant retail business.The company has successful business especially with chefs, restaurants and hotels in Northern Ireland.Prep House has experienced exceptional growth to  people, including  in the modern factory, from the three employed when the business began.Sales have more than tripled since then. In addition, the company has invested almost poundm in creating a state-of-the-art factory and new product kitchen close to the centre of the village.Awards for taste and quality have also followed from the UK Quality Food and Drink, Great Taste Awards and the Blas na hEireann Irish National Awards..prettyPhoto

title: Disappointing Down miss out on promotion
story: DOWNrsquoS hopes of promotion to Division  ended in deep disappointment at Pairc Esler on Sunday.Hopes were high that Louth would prove to be a stepping stone to promotion and a place in the isional final at Croke Park.However, those hopes were blown away largely thanks to an inept display of scoring.The sorry truth is that Down went  minutes without registering a single score and managed only three points in the first half when they had advantage of a gale behind them.Down had gone into the game at the top of the table following five wins in a row, but this loss, coupled with defeat in the opening game of the campaign against Laois, proved to be their undoing.Laois guaranteed themselves promotion with a - to - win over Carlow. Joining them will be Louth or Westmeath.Down manager Paddy Tally admitted afterwards: ldquoWe didnrsquot put enough scores on the board with a strong breeze behind us and it cost us.ldquoOur destiny was in our hands today and we didnrsquot grab it. It was there for the taking. We didnrsquot play well enough. Itrsquos fiercely disappointing.Down hit three points in the opening nine minutes and then didnrsquot score again until Darren OrsquoHagan found the back of the net in the nd minute to spark a revival that fell just short.Ryan Johnston, Conor Poland and Caolan Mooney scored those early points, but after that there was little threat from the Down attack.Their attacking play for the rest of the half was haphazard in the extreme. The Down sharp shooters lost their way and tried their luck from distance. The result was aimless, wayward shooting.Louth, who deservedly led - to - at half time, made a decisive burst with eight unanswered points either side of the break.Full forward Sam Mulroy bagged half their tally, all five of his points coming from frees, during that purple patch, with midfielders James Calfand Tommy Durnin also registering.With  minutes to go Louth led - to - and then came the Down revival, led by Darren OrsquoHagan who scored a goal and a point.The goal came after Donal OrsquoHarersquos initial shot was brilliantly kept in by Connaire Harrison. The ball fell to OrsquoHagan, who dummied and then fired his shot into the net.Harrison,who looked impressive,registered a great point and when Paul Devlin and then OrsquoHagan also pointed, the gap was down to a single score.Down, who had mounted a number of successful comebacks during the campaign, looked as though they were going to mount another great escape.But it was not to be. They failed to score in the final eight minutes, including stoppage time.Down: R Burns R Wells, R McAleenan D Guinness, P Laverty, K McKernan, C Flanagan, D OrsquoHaganJ Flynn, C MooneyR Johnston , C Poland , B OrsquoHagan D OrsquoHare, J Johnston. Subs: P Devlinfor Flanagan , C Quinn for J Johnston , S Fegan for Laverty , B McArdle for Wells , C Harrisonfor B OrsquoHagan . Yellow cards: J Johnston , D OrsquoHagan Louth: F Sheeky J Craven, E Carolan A Williams, B Duffy, F Donohoe, J Clutterbuck T Durnin , J CalfC Brannigan, C Downey, J McEneaney A McDonnell, S Mulroy , D Byrne .Subs: E Duffy for Brannigan , D Maguire for Clutterbuck , C Early for Calf , C McKeever for McDonnell , R Burns for McEneaney . Yellow card: E Carolan .Referee: J Hickey .Down -Louth -ALLIANZ NFL DIVISION .prettyPhoto

title: Dowie books final spot with last minute winner
story: HOLDERS Ballynagross will face Killough in the Harry Clarke Cup final on Easter Monday.A stoppage time goal from stand-in captain Daniel Dowie saw off Mourne Rovers at Bignian Park on Friday night.Dowie, who took over as skipper after Daniel Taggart had to be substituted in the th minute, became Captain Fantastic when he headed home Kieran Taggartrsquos free kick from the right hand touchline at the far post.It was tough luck on Rovers who battled all night only to be dealt a killer blow at the death.They had fallen behind on  minutes when Rory McDonnell fired Ballynagross in the lead, but they looked set to take the game to extra time when Gareth McDowell grabbed the equaliser with  minutes remaining.Dowie, who played a key role in Ballynagrossrsquos Clarke Cup and Division  double last season, said afterwards that he was delighted to get to another final mdash the clubrsquos third in four seasons.ldquoThings havenrsquot been going so well in the Premier League this season but itrsquos nice to get into a final again, he remarked.ldquoWe didnrsquot play as well as we should have tonight, especially in the first half, but we came out battling in the second and deserved it, I think. Rovers gave it a good go at the end but the late goal killed the game off.Ballynagross, who beat Ballyvea - after extra time in last yearrsquos final, were given a stern test by Rovers, who last won the Clarke Cup in the - season when they beat Ballynagross -.Rovers created the only two chances of the first  minutes. Cormac Poland struck a free kick against the top of the bar in the third minute and Gareth McDowell was almost in, but lsquoGross keeper Cathail Arnold was out quickly to take the ball off his toe.There was little to excite the crowd with only a couple of Dowie shots whizzing wide, while at the other end Arnold saved from a Ryan Sloan shot.Arnoldrsquos hands were stung by a fierce shot from Ryan Clerkin after Kyle Morris and Ryan Sloan had worked the opening and with the half almost up Rovers keeper Steven Doran ran the fullof the pitch to take a free kick inside the D which was blocked.Rovers defender Ciaran OrsquoHare sustained a nasty injury four minutes into the second half when he received a kick to his right kneecap, although he was able to hobble on to the end.It was an unfortunate day, injury wise, for the Rovers defence. Mark Trimble had to be substituted after  minutes and following OrsquoHarersquos mishap, Martin McGrath also had to leave the field in the th minute.With Deaglan Arnold becoming ever more influential for lsquoGross, the breakthrough came in the th minute when Rory McDonnell neatly slipping the ball past Doran after finding space in the box.But less than  minutes later Rovers were level. Substitute Ryan OrsquoHare sent over a corner which pinged around the the box before Gareth McDowell swung on the ball to send it past the unsighted keeper.Just as the crowd were getting prepared for extra time, man of the match Dowie arrived at the far post to settle the tie.Ballynagross: Cathail Arnold, Patrick Smith, Paul OrsquoReilly, Connor Marron, Aaron Beattie , Deaglan Arnold, Rory McDonnell , Matthew Rooney, Daniel Taggart , Declan Dowie, Donal McCavera. Subs not used: John Shields, Mark Magill.Mourne Rovers: Steven Doran, Martin McGrath , Mark Trimble , Ciaran OrsquoHare, Sean Clarke, Cormac Poland, Ryan Sloan, Gareth McDowell, Kyle Morris, Ronan McAlinden, Ryan Clerkin. Subs not used: Deaglan Morgan, Ronan McDowell, Conor Shields.Ballynagross Mourne Rovers HARRY CLARKE CUP SEMI-FINAL.prettyPhoto

title: Final journey of mother of three
story: A DEVOTED mother and bride-to-be was laid to rest in her wedding dress a week after going missing at a friendrsquos hen party.Ruth Maguirersquos coffin was carried by her fianceacute Jim Grfin as he and their young children said a last farewell on Saturday at the church where the couple would have been married.The  year-old nursing assistant from Burren Meadow in Newcastle had planned toto her home church in North Belfast in August for their wedding.Their children mdash Tyler , Lydiaand five year-old Oliver mdash were also due to be attendants at St Vincent De Paul Church service in Ligoniel.Ms Maguirersquos body was recovered from Carlingford Lough last Monday after she had been reported missing late that Saturday night.She was part of a large group of women staying in Carlingford to celebrate a friendrsquos wedding.It is believed she fell into the water after getting disorientated on leaving her friends in a pub across the road.Her death was one of two tragedies in the Carlingford area that weekend.Best friends Shane McAnallen from Castlewellan and Martin Patterson from Bryansford died in a car crash hours before the tragic news that Ms Maguire had died was confirmed.All three young people were connected to Bryansford GAC and their deaths have stunned the local community.A candlelight vigil was held in Carlingford on Sunday evening to remember the the three people lost and offer some comfort to their families.Organised by the Cooley Community Alert Facebook group, a local choir sang hymns and representatives from the victimsrsquo families, An Garda Siacuteochaacutena, local clergy, local councillors, Greenore Coast Guard, Kilkeel and Newcastle RNLI, HM Coastguard, Dundalk Sub Aqua, Ambulance Service and Red Cross all turned out to pay their respects.Before her funeral, Ms Maguirersquos partner paid a touching tribute to her on Facebook calling her ldquohis soul mate.He added: ldquoRuth will be missed more than she will ever know by myself and our three children and families.The well-attended Requiem Mass was conducted by Fr Darach Mac Giolla Cathaacutein.Children and adults from Bryansford GAC in Newcastle, where she volunteered as a coach, stood outside to make a guard of honour for a much respected junior coach.Members of Newcastle RNLI, who were involved in the search and recovery, helped carry the coffin.One floral tribute in the hearse simply spelt out lsquoFriendrsquo.Inside, a family photograph of Ms Maguire and her family was brought to the alter.Fr Mac Giolla Cathaacutein told mourners that Ms Maguire was a young woman who dedicated her le to others, either as a mother, carer, coach and Irish dancing teacher.She was also ldquoslow to take offence and quick to forgive and despite being the youngest of her family, ldquowas the boss who kept her siblings on their toes.He said that her family ldquowas at the heart of her le.Addressing her children, Fr Mac Giolla Cathaacutein added: ldquoToday, remember that your mummy loved you so much and yoursquoll have so many people around you to help you and comfort you.ldquoRemember there is always hope, always faith, always love.Ms Maguire was buried in Carnamoney Cemetery in Newtownabbey. She is also survived by her parents, Geraldine and Malachy, and siblings Raymond, Rachel and Ryan.Ms Maguire worked for the South Eastern Health and Social Care Trust in Daisy Hill Hospital in Newry and was a casual leisure attendant at the Newcastle Centre.Her colleagues described her as a ldquomuch loved and valued colleague and a person who was ldquohard-working and popular with colleagues and customers alike.One of Ms Maguirersquos friends set up a donation page to support the family which already at pound, has surpassed its target.Leighann Flood wrote on the JustGiving site: ldquoRuth was the most loving, hardworking and caring mother to her three beautul children Tyler, Lydia and Oliver.ldquoAlong with her fianceacute Jim, they worked tirelessly to give their children the best that they possibly could in le.ldquoFrom gymnastics, Irish dancing, football and local GAA, Ruth made it her le to make sure the children attended as much as possible so that they would get the most out of their childhood.ldquoWe have set this page up to give the childrenas much help as possible so that they may continue on with all their extra curriculars during this heartbreaking time in their young lives.bull To donate go to https:goo.gl mLBfQB..prettyPhoto

title: Four week delay with work on Irish Street regeneration
story: WORK on a near pound, regeneration street scheme in Irish Street will not be completed on time.The Department for Communities and Newry, Mourne and Down Council are funding the initiative to provide new granite footpaths, lighting and street furniture which was originally scheduled to complete at the end of this week.However, the scheme will take an additional four weeks to conclude with contractors not due to finish in Irish Street until the end of next month.Council officials have explained that as Phoenix Gas took longer than expected to complete work in Irish Street as part of a multi-million pound investment to provide residents and business owners with access to mains gas, the public realm contractor was subsequently delayed.The Department for Communities is making a pound, contribution to the environmental improvement scheme, with the local authority providing the remainder of the cash for the eagerly-awaited revamp.The heritage value of the Irish Street area is something council officials are not only keen to preserve, but build upon as they work with the Department for Communities to maximise the potential of this part of the town.A one-way traffic system has been in operation for the past few weeks and this is expected to conclude once the public realm work has been completed.Downpatrick councillor Dermot Curran described the major investment as ldquolong overdue, and said the area missed out on previous public realm schemes due to the presence of heavy security fortications surrounding the townrsquos police base which is now located at the Downshire Civic Centre.Cllr Curran said he hopes that the work will be supplemented with funding to encourage business owners to improve the appearance of their respective buildings in a location which forms part of the townrsquos conservation area.He said he had no doubt that Irish Street will benefit from the public realm scheme, but warned more investment is required at this part of Downpatrick.ldquoIrish Street missed out on much-needed investment for decades and I hope that exciting plans for the regeneration of the former police station site and a number of adjacent buildings, which are empty and derelict, will come to fruition, Cllr Curran continued.ldquoThis particular site offers major retail potential and its development would attract more shoppers to the town, with the increased footfall providing a boost for existing traders.Cllr Curran added: ldquoThe removal of former security measures around the old police base opened the area up and Irish Street is ripe for redevelopment. I am confident that the completed public realm scheme will signicantly enhance the ambitious plans to develop a new retail and commercial centre at this part of Downpatrick.It was confirmed recently that the former police base will not be bulldozed as part of the ambitious multi-million pound plan to regenerate this part of the town.The building mdash which enjoys protected status mdash is to remain a key feature of the proposed redevelopment project which, in addition to new retail and commercial space, could also include an element of housing provision.Council officials insist the former police basersquos listed building status is not an impediment to the development of the site and view preserving the former station as an opportunity and a challenge, insisting it very much remains part of the overall development project and potentially could be utilised as an attractive entrance feature.To date, senior retailers including Marks and Spencer and Home Bargains have expressed an interest in opening new premises at the proposed retail complex which will be built on a huge area of land stretching back as as far as St Patrickrsquos Avenue.A council spokeswoman confirmed yesterday that while the public realm works were scheduled to complete on March , a utilities company was required to undertake work in Irish Street before the public realm contractor was able to get on site.She added: ldquoDue to unforeseen circumstances experienced by the utilities company on site which required their attention, it resulted in a delay to the completion date of the overall public realm scheme. It is anticipated now that the public realm scheme will be completed before the end of April..prettyPhoto

title: From the pages of the Down Recorder%2C March 27%2C 1979
story: DOWNPATRICK mdash Downpatrick was in the middle of a rubbish tangle this week with unemptied bins and litter boxes left piled in housing estates and on many of the townrsquos footpaths.High winds and scavenging dogs added to the problem as waste became strewn over large areas.Council bin collections were running behind schedule from anything between one day and five days and angry housewives and traders were left wondering what had gone wrong.The worst affected areas were Scotch Street and Irish Street where shoppers had to walk on roadways to avoid the piles of rubbish.Callers to the Recorder claimed that phone queries to the council offices were either ldquofobbed off or nobody was prepared to talk to them.Traffic to the townrsquos main dump at Inch was a steady trickle throughout Monday as traders and domestic ratepayers carried out their own disposal.Domestic collections have been so erratic, particularly in the last ten days, that people now do not know when to leave out their bins for collection.Mr Seamus Byrne, Down Council clerk and chief executive, told the Recorder what had gone wrong and promised that normal schedules should be resumed later this week.He explained that bin crews were on holiday on Monday of last week, but for the remainder of the week only half the Downpatrick crew turned in for work, the others having booked off sick.CROSSGAR mdash A former Crossgar man is making plans for a daring world recored crossing of the North Atlantic in a  feet rowing boat.Twenty-seven year-old Kenneth Kerr, formerly from Drumaghlis, will head out from St Johnrsquos, Newfoundland, and will cross , miles of sea to the west coast of Ireland. He reckons that his tiny craft, Bass Conqueror, will take about  days to complete the epic voyage.Kenneth now lives in East Lothian in Scotland. Formerly in the Royal Navy, he served aboard the hunter-killer submarine HMS Conqueror based at Faslane.His small boat has been specially fitted out for the voyage and he says he has had tremendous help from many organisations and iniduals.ldquoI am not going for the fastest time, he said. ldquoRather, I am attempting to make the trip in the smallest craft. If you are going to all the trouble of making such an attempt you have to do something dramatic.BALLYNAHINCH mdash War is to be waged by irate Down councillors and education board members over the scrapping of plans for a swimming pool in Ballynahinch.Annoyance came to ahead after a joint deputation was firmly told by the Department of Education that a pool could not be afforded before ,at all.Until a few weeks ago the council and the education board believed that a learner pool would be included in plans for a new leisure centre.The deputation met officials in an effort to get facts straightened out. Afterwards Mr Cecil Kirkwood, vice-chairman of the board, said how ldquopeeved he felt at being sternly lectured on the expense of providing swimming pools.Mrs Ethel Smyth, Down councillor and board member, expressed her ldquodisgust at the outcome of the deputationrsquos visit.ldquoThe worst thing about the whole matter is that local councillors and the people of Ballynahinch have been led up the garden path. Everybody fully believed that the whole scheme was to go ahead, she said.ldquoAs there are over , schoolchildren in Ballynahinch and district, who would be the prime users of the pool, it seems a crying shame to think of scrapping the pool and thus deprive the young people of the district the chance to learn to swim.NEWCASTLE mdash Newcastle, where the mountains of Mourne sweep down to the sea, has already been regarded as a world renowned seaside resort. But it seems that not everyone has heard of it, especially here in Ireland!At a recent leisure fair in Dublin nine out of every ten young people interviewed had never heard of the resort immortalised, we thought, by Percy Frenchrsquos famous song.That was the shock in store for members of the Heart of Down Accommodation Association who manned a stand at the Dublin exhibition.An Association spokesman said: ldquoThis type of response, coupled with the number of requests for information, demonstrates a real need either for an office, or at least a representative of the Northern Ireland Tourist Board to be based in the Republic to distribute literature and holiday information to travel agents and the public.Meanwhile, the Association has been directing its own promotional ideas further afield. This month representatives have had discussions with two parties of Canadian travel agents, an airline and a cross-channel ferry service with a view to increasing holiday traffic to Down.CARRICKMANNON mdash Carrickmannon Primary School, near Ballygowan, was given the kiss of le this week by local education chiefs.The South EasternEducation and Library Board has agreed that the school should be kept in operation and that a permanent principal should be appointed.Their decision will have to go to the Department of Education for approval, but it ends almost four years of anguish for everyone associated with the school.The threat of closure had been hanging over the school with pupil numbers dwindling from  to  and with the present principal expressing her wish to retire in August this year.The Boardrsquos Educational Services Committee decided that while the enrolment trend should a gradual decline in numbers it should be taken into account that the Ballygowan area had a hew housing development which could well stop the decline.Approval will be asked for a scheme to repair the school building and to provide modern toilet facilities. An assistant teacher, who has been employed at Carrickmannon in a temporary capacity for three years, will be offered a permanent post.KILLYLEAGH mdash The world famous hypnotist, Edwin Heath, is to become the latest big showbiz attraction to make an appearance in St Maryrsquos Hall, Killyleagh.Edwin will top the bill with the best in country music, Crawford Bell and Steel Rail, at a show on Friday, April . The compere is Tom Raymond. Admission is pound. and proceeds are in aid of the hallrsquos badminton and bowls clubs.DERRYBOY mdash Parents of children at Derryboye Primary School are not making proper use of the parking lay-by outside the school.At a recent meeting of the South Eastern Education and Library Boardrsquos Finance Committee, members were told that vehicles had been parking directly outside the school entrance, sometimes double parking.The committee was told that parents had alleged that there was no room in the afternoon at the -yard long lay-by for cars calling to collect children.But the committee also heard that there was ample room for the cars to be accommodated in the lay-by at all times.After discussing the matter it was agreed that no action should be taken an that it should be suggested to the school management committee that steps should be taken to ensure the proper use of this lay-by.PORTAFERRY mdash An old church is Portaferry is now almost certain to be demolished, despite recent efforts to have it preserved. The building at Meeting Lane has been holding up plans by the local roads service to open a pound, car park to cater for  vehicles.HOCKEY mdash Down High schoolgirl Anne Norwood played on Saturday for the Schoolgirlsrsquo Vice-Presidentrsquos hockey XI. Anne, from Saintfield, is captain of the school hockey team and played last season for the Ulster B hockey team..prettyPhoto

title: Parties invited to apply for site at new £8m Carryduff complex
story: PLANS have been unveiled to invest poundm in a major new retail and commercial development at the former Carryduff Shopping Centre.Leading Belfast-based property investment company Causeway Asset Management is spearheading the exciting new regeneration initiative at the . acre location at Church Road.Branded as lsquoThe Villagersquo, the multi-million pound project includes the renovation of the former SuperValu site and the addition of three prime retail units and a restaurant.Two existing retail units are also being retained, with plans to build  apartments, complete with car parking and extensive landscaping.Causeway Asset Management has confirmed that it is currently in talks with a number of prospective tenants and is inviting interest.Planning for the ambitious project was secured last November with ongoing demolition works at the site due to complete shortly with the new-build phase set to commence in the summer, paving the way for wider regeneration in the area.Causeway Asset Management Director Brian Kearney said Carryduff residents wanted to see the Church Road site rejuvenated into a contemporary space that will attract investment and footfall, while meeting the needs of the local community.ldquoThe scheme at The Village will combine modern retail units fit for st century occupiers alongside contemporary housing to restore the site into a vibrant economic hub, he explained.The approved regeneration scheme is designed to breathe new le into the site and has been widely supported by councillors in Lisburn and Castlereagh Council.Cllr Brian Hanvey said he was pleased to see the plans for The Village taking a step forward.ldquoThe regeneration of this site into a retail and residential destination has been supported by the community and I am looking forward to seeing the positive impact it will have as the scheme becomes a reality in the coming months, he added.Cllr Michael Henderson said the approved plans by Causeway Asset Management for the former shopping centre site would ldquobring a new retail hub to the centre of this community.He added: ldquoIt is great to see that the regeneration is moving forward. There is demand in the area for a erse retail offering.Lisney and Lambert Smith Hampton have been appointed joint letting agents for the upcoming retail units, with details on the release of the residential element of the scheme due to be announced later this year.Interested parties can request information on the available retail opportunities by visiting www.thevillagecarryduff..prettyPhoto

title: Pensioner’s car pelted by yobs
story: A PUBLIC protest has called for an end to trouble at the Killough Road in Downpatrick after three pensioners cars were targeted by children throwing stones last week.In one particularly frightening incident, a elderly man was showered with fragments of broken glass after the driverrsquos window of his car was smashed. He sustained cuts to his hands.There were two other similar incidents, prompting the Flying Horse Ward Community Forum to stage a protest last Friday.The Killough Road mdash which bisects the Model Farm and Flying Horse estates mdash has been a regular trouble hot spot over recent years.While things have been relatively quiet over recent months, the community group is keen to ensure that the recent stone throwing incidents are not a precursor to more trouble in the weeks and months ahead.Concerned at the frightening impact the attacks on cars has had on three elderly couples, the community group says the trouble must stop now.Forum members are also deeply concerned that those who threw missiles at the vehicles are of primary school age and confirmed they plan to speak with school principals in the area.Community group chairwoman Lisa Perry said the reduction in trouble at the Killough Road had been noticeable, insisting it would be a great pityit ed.She said last weekrsquos protest, which was supported by local politicians and the PSNI, was organised toprovide an opportunity for the community to stand together and demonstrate that the recent trouble is simply not acceptable Ms Perry said it was vital that parents know where their children are and what they are doing.ldquoChildren need to respect the community where they live and the people of this area who should not have to put up with such behaviour. We are appealing to anyone who knows the identity of those involved to pass that information to the police.Ms Perry said the message must go out that stoning cars is not acceptable and that those responsible will not be be allowed to get away with what they are doing.ldquoWe do not want another summer of trouble, the community group chairwoman declared. ldquoPeople are very shocked at what happened last week and the fact that it was pensioners who were targeted.ldquoThe protest was a direct response to what happened last week and an opportunity to send out the strongest possible message that this behaviour will not be tolerated.Ms Perry added: ldquoThe clear evenings will soon be here and it is important that the community stands together and demonstrates that there is to be no more trouble. No one wants to see more negative headlines about trouble at this part of the town.ldquoIt does not bear thinking about what would happena driver whose car is stoned loses control of the vehicle and crashes into pedestrians or someonersquos home.ldquoThose who throw missiles at cars need to realise the potential consequences of what they are doing.Forum members hope the driver injured last week will recover from his injuries and are encouraging people who are targeted by troublemakers to inform the police so that the incidents are officially logged.One of the drivers whose car was targeted has warned that someone could dietheir vehicle is hit by a missile.The man, who did not wish to be identied, added: ldquoTo a child, it is just throwing a stone, but the shock of a missile hitting a car could lead to a serious incident. This behaviour must stop and parents have a responsibility to ensure their children are not involved. It will be too late doing something after a serious crash.ldquoThe children who threw stones at my car are about  years old. Why are their parents letting them do this  The missile missed my car by a tiny fraction and I was lucky. But what happens when your luck runs out behind the wheel of your car ldquoThere is a serious incident waiting to happen and the residents in the Flying Horse and Model Farm want this trouble to stop..prettyPhoto

title: Politicians calling for review of babies post mortem cases
story: THE controversial decision to send babies to England for post-mortem topped the agenda during a meeting between local politicians and senior health chiefs last week.South Down MLA Colin McGrath and Downpatrick councillor John Trainor met with senior officials from the Department of Health to discuss the move to send babies to the Alder Hey Childrenrsquos Hospital in Liverpool.The Assemblyman said the issue of childhood post-mortems had been traumatic for many families. He said that in addition to the trauma of suddenly losing a young child, they now faced the added pressure of having to have their child flown to England for post-mortem.Mr McGrath said it was his understanding that the issue impacted on around  families a year, highlighting the importance of doing everything possible for families.ldquoThere are a number of considerations here, suggested Mr McGrath. ldquoWe have to consider the period of time to conclude the post-mortem andthe child to their family for burial.ldquoI am very heartened to hear that the present model involving Liverpool is maintaining the turnaround times. What is also of the utmost importance is supporting the childrsquos family and I am glad to hear that there are bereavement support teams here for families.Mr McGrath added: ldquoThis is not going to be an easy process, however what is absolutely vital is that we get the right long term solution and my colleagues and I will be pressing the government department for that.ldquoCllr Trainor and I met departmental officials to ascertain how we can progress matters for the peace of mind of families here.Explaining the background to sending babies to Liverpool for post-mortem, Cllr Trainor said the paediatric pathologist who was involved in carrying out these procedures in Belfast moved from his current post and there was no one available to fill the position.ldquoFrom our meeting, it is apparent that there is a shortage here of paediatric pathologists and this is why the link with Liverpool has been implemented as a short term solution, he said.Cllr Trainor added: ldquoThe Department of Health is also looking at the possibility of an all island approach. However, such a process would take some time to develop as we look at the possibility of a standardised level of care between north and south.Local health campaigners are also seeking a meeting with senior health chiefs to discuss the issue of child post-mortems being held in Liverpool.The Down Community Health Committee believes thatpriority was given to funding and enticement for the training of pathologists, post-mortems could continue to be carried out on a regional basis.At one of its recent meetings, Mrs Anne Trainor, suggested that the possibility of pathologists travelling to Northern Ireland periodically from England, Scotland, Wales and further afield could be considered.She described the decision to perform post-mortems in Liverpool as ldquosickening and immoral and argued health officials should have done more to continue the service.Mrs Trainor added: ldquoFor women who have had a miscarriage or whose baby dies, it is the single worst thing that is ever going to happen in your le.ldquoYou will lose parents, aunts and uncles, husbands and wives, but you will never experience the pain and heartbreak of losing a child. For health officials to suggest that a child is wrapped up like a package and sent across the water for a post mortem is cruel. To send parents on such a journey is heartbreaking..prettyPhoto

title: Red High one step to Croker
story: THE Gaelic footballers of St Patrickrsquos Grammar School, Downpatrick, are just one game away from Croke Park.The Red High take on Roscommon Christian Brothers School in an All-Ireland B Schools Championship semi-final at the UCD sports campus in Dublin tonight.Throw-in is at .pm and the locals are looking for the same level of support which powered them to victory in last weekrsquos MacLarnon Cup final.They will be cheered on by at least two busloads of supporters from the school and it hoped that many more will make their way south.Declan Morgan, one of the team coaches, said the players are focused on the job ahead, despite securing the MacLarnon Cup for the first time in  years.ldquoWhen we started out our sole aim was to win the MacLarnon Cup, he said. ldquoBut the players have switched their focus and are determined to put in a good performance.The All-Ireland final is scheduled for next Friday, April . Standing in the Red Highrsquos way are formidable opponents.Roscommon CBS, with a couple of county minor players in their ranks, convincingly won the Connacht championship final by a whopping - to - margin.ldquoThey are obviously a very good team with a potent forward line, Mr Morgan continued. ldquoWe are certainly mindful of what they can do and so we will have to get our defensive and midfield match-ups correct so that we can stop the ball going to their forwards.However, it seems unlikely that the Red High will alter their playing style after producing a scintillating display to defeat hotly tipped Derry side Cathair Dhoire by - to - in the MacLarnon final.It was a performance full of flair and creativity, coupled with defensive ruggedness and ruthless finishing.Two goals from man of the match Tim Prenter proved to be the dference between the sides at the end, but there were heroes all over the field.Goalkeeper Eoin Maginn produced two wonder saves during a crucial period in the second half when the sides were level and there wereterric performances also from Eoin Rooney and Jack Harbinson in defence, Ruairi OrsquoHare, who banged over six points mdash four of them from frees mdash and Ronan Connor, who added three great points.St Patrickrsquos have won the All-Ireland B title on two previous occasions mdash in  and  mdash and would dearly love to get their hands on the Paddy Drummond Cup for the third time.With the added incentive of lining out at Croke Park, the Red High lads will not be lacking in motivation.Coach Morgan said: ldquoAfter the MacLarnon final there was a great sense of elation in the school. Everyone was over the moon, but even a day later the players were eager to get back to training.ldquoTo get to Croke Park is the dream of anyone involved in Gaelic games.ldquoIt is the pinnacle for all GAA players. Our boys want to continue their fantastic run and want get to Croke Park.He added: ldquoWe had fantastic support in the MacLarnon Cup and we need it againwe are to reach the All-Ireland final..prettyPhoto

title: Reduced family centre rates for leisure centres
story: NEW family membership prices for Down Leisure Centre and Ballymote Sports and Wellbeing Centre will come into effect next month.For one full-paying monthly member, additional family members will be able to pay just pound for the leisure centre and pound for Ballymote per month.Full monthly membership of Downpatrick centre and Ballymote costs pound. and pound. respectively.However, a new price of pound. direct debit payment per month for gym only at Ballymote and Newcastle has also been recommended with a pound per month for people aged over  and the less able to use the gym, swim and health suite facilities.The prices were approved at last Thursdayrsquos meeting of Newry, Mourne and Downrsquos Active and Healthy Communities committee.Known as the household membership bolt-on pricing structure, the prices require to be rubber-stamped by the full council which meets next Monday night.Cllr Gareth Sharvin, committee chairman, welcomed the new prices structure, which was proposed by Cllr Roisin Howell and seconded by Cllr Brian Quinn.He said the new prices represented ldquogreat savings for families in the Downpatrick and Lecale area.ldquoFurther to the household bolt on membership, the council will be introducing a new price model to encourage junior participation within leisure centre swimming pools, where leisure centre customers who have an active membership account, a discounted rate of pound. per child will be offered compared to pound. for - years old with an accompanying adult member, he added.ldquoThatrsquos another great saving for families to avail of at the Down Leisure Centre. Under four years of age continues to be free of charge.The new prices were welcomed by Cllr Howell and Downpatrick Sinn Fein candidate Oonagh Hanlon.Cllr Howell said: ldquoI am delighted that this review has been completed and bolt on membership for families and multiple members in one household has been agreed. Swimming concessions are also approved for children of members.Ms Hanlon added: ldquoIt is vitally important that this wonderful facility is accessible to everyone and pricing should not be a barrier for families who want to avail of the facilities..prettyPhoto

title: Ring wins Ulster National
story: SO large was the attendance at Downpatrick opening meeting of the year on Sunday, featuring the toalsbet Ulster National, that overflow car parks had to be opened and reports indicate that there was a tailback to the crossroads on the Newcastle Road.Nine of the  declared runners in the feature race over three mile four furlongs came under starters orders with the joint bottom weight School Lane in the colours of Rathfriland owner Francis Doyle, setting out to make the running under Adam Shott, followed closely by the rest of the line up.School Lane still held the lead over the final fence and looked like he was going to provide Newry trainer Liam Lennon with his biggest success to date, but then Amaulino, who had beaten Lennonrsquos charge in a recent race at Leopardstown, came with a late challenge under Andrew Ring to win by three-and-a-half s with Danse Away back in third.For successful trainer Keith Watson from Killylea, Co Armagh, it was his biggest ever success. The winner is owned by the Armagh-based Springfield partnership and had been laid out for this race. Starting prices:  ,  ,  .Meath-based Gordon Elliott, champion trainer at the track in the past two years, made the perfect start to the new year when he recorded a double.His first success of the day came in the third race, the Molson Coors Handicap Hurdle, in which he saddled two runners, Take A Turn and From Eden. It was the - outsider Take A Turn, ridden by Keith Donoghue who beat the - favourite From Eden, the mount of Jack Kennedy, with Bridge Native at   back in third. For Keith it was his second win of the weekend.The double game in the Molson Coors Pro Am flat race when Lisa OrsquoNeil rode the   favourite, Multactorial, to a steady success over   outsider Legacy Thor, ridden by the popular Larne rider Ben Crawford. Back in third came Fasola Tido.The yearrsquos racing at the popular venue got underway with the Connollyrsquos Red Mills Irish EBF Auction maiden hurdle and it proved to be a race for the large number of bookies with   shot Mister Eddman, ridden by lb claimer Danny Hand, winning in good style from Lady Ischia, ridden by Barry Geraghty with Mateka Pakka third. The winner is trained near Dublin by the in-form Oliver McKiernan.Also over hurdles was the valuable WKD Rated hurdle. Despite good prize money paid to the first five past the post, only six took part.Laverteen in the Gigginstown House colours took the advantage after the final flight under Sean Flanagan, who was riding his th winner of the NH season to beat the   favourite Count Simon in the colours of the race sponsor Joe and Pat Sloan from Templepatrick, with Slippery Serpent third. The   winner is trained in Meath by Noel Meade.The Tote supporting Downpatrick Racecourse Handicap Chase saw Slemish, a recent second at the Armagh point-to-point, following a long absence, prove to be a ready winner, held up at the rear of the nine runner field by top amateur Jamie Codd.The winner was sent clear in the closing stages to win from Allduckornodinner, ridden by Gold Cup-winning jockey Paul Townend, and the  year old veteran Honest Rubber, ridden by Danny Mullins. SP:  ,  , favourite  .The winner in the famous Potts colours is trained in Co Meath by Jim Dreaper.Also over fences was the Boardsmills Sires Maiden Hunters Chase. All bar one of the declared runners took part, despite the change in going that saw a lot of non-runners during the afternoon.This race saw one of the easiest winners of the day with Billaway, a rare runner in a Hunter Chase for Champion and Gold Cup winning trainer Willie Mullins.This one, ridden by the trainerrsquos son Patrick, came clear to win by  s from Tareesher in the colours of Downpatrick owner Paddy Madine, ridden by Deckie Lavery who hit many headlines in recent days, following his Cheltenham ban and successful appeal. The hard ridden Like A Demon finished third. Our Bonus trained by Keith Watson took fourth. SP: -, -, -.At Thurles on Saturday, Belfast jockey Jordan Canavan recorded his third career success mdash and ssecond in Ireland mdash when getting Iconic Lady, trained by his boss Robert Tyner in Co Cork, up to win the Adape Manor opportunity maiden hurdle by a head.The previous evening at Dundalk, Moira trainer Lee Smyth saddled   shot Lady Goa, ridden by Wayne Lordon, to victory.Downpatrick Racecourse extended birthday wishes to Comber farmer and former veteran rider Alec Murdock. Belfast bookie Ray Nicholas, Calor Gas man Roy Kerr from Ballygowan and also Frank McLeigh and Therese McCartan.Ballynoe jockey Ross McLeigh is now based with Colin McBratney following a long spell with Tony Martin.This Saturday itrsquos the Portrush point-to-point . title: Schoolgirl raises funds for Cystic Fibrosis charity
story: BIG-HEARTED schoolgirl Rebecca Thompson went for the chop in aid of two charities close to her heart.The nine year-old from Crossgar got a massive  inches cut off her hair, which was transformed into a stylish new bob at Downpatrickrsquos Beehive Salon last week.She has raised pound so far for the Cystic Fibrosis Trust in honour of her friend, two year-old Lorcaacuten Maguire, from Downpatrick, who has the condition.The Little Princess Trust charity, which provides real-hair wigs for children and young people with cancer, will also benefit from receiving her hair.Rebecca, who is a pupil at Holy Family Primary School in Teconnaught, said: ldquoI was a wee bit nervous on the day about getting my hair cut but Irsquom really glad that I raised so much money. But I really love my new hair cut and feel very proud of myself.ldquoBy donating my hair, Irsquom able to help out two charities. I would like to thank everyone who supported me and hope that Lorcaacuten and everyone with cystic fibrosis will get the medicine they need soon.Lorcaacutenrsquos parents and the Cystic Fibrosis Trust is calling on the Government to make the le-extending drug orkambi available free on the NHS as soon as possible..prettyPhoto

title: Seaforde win final Division 1 Cup final
story: NEWCASTLE Presbyterian Church Hall was the venue for the Lecale League Division  Cup final between hot favourites Seaforde and underdogs St Macartanrsquos, who went into this match knowing they would be playing their bowls in Division  next season.All credit to the Saints as they made the Young Farmers work hard to secure the league and cup double.Francie McGreevy and his rink of Anne and Raymond Gelston and Betty McClurg got them off to a great start as they had an - win over Alan Loughlin. On the other mat Ann and Edwin Patterson, Don McNamara and Graham Christie replied with a - win against Collie Brown.The next run proved very tight as Trevor Perry, Paul Fisher, Hugh Burns and Peter Christie secured three shots on their last end for a - win against John Gavin, while nothing ended up separating the rinks skipped by Joe Kennedy and David Boal after David scored two shots also on his last end to finish the game at -.At half-time and with Seaforde only holding a slim three-shot advantage, the big question was could the Saints keep up the good work to possibly cause another upset.After the break John Gavin led his rink of Liz Kennedy, John McGreevy and Maurice Cullen to a close - win over the Loughlin four, but once again it would be the Graham Christie four who would come to Seafordersquos rescue as they had an - win over the Kennedy rink to put them six shots up going into the final games.It wasnrsquot to be for St Macartanrsquos as Seaforde showed the better nerve. David Boal won his game against Collie Brown - and Peter Christie finishing the match with a - win over Francie McGreevy for the ten-shot overall victory.League chairman Mr Eddie Dornan presented the cup and Division  trophy to Seaforde vice-captains Don McNamara and David Boal.On this sort of form it will only be a short visit back into Division  for the Saints, who played some great bowls to put pressure on Seaforde and in last weekrsquos victory over St Marys in the semi-final.Congratulations to Seaforde on completing the double in what was a record-breaking season for them. Whoanyone, can rise to challenge them next season as they prepare to defend both title A big thank you to St Michaelrsquos for hosting this match and providing a great supper for the players and spectators.ST MACARTANrsquoS SEAFORDE YFC .prettyPhoto

title: Students recognised
story: TWO young environmentalists from Shimna Integrated College in Newcastle were feted at a top awards ceremony in London for their work protecting the local environment.Brothers Daraand Lorcan McAnultyrepresented the schoolrsquos Shoots and Roots group which was shortlisted in the Jane Goodall Awards Ceremony at the Barbican Centre last week.Shimna was one of  finalists out of of over , schools in the UK.Dara already is an award-winning environmental blogger and author and has won numerous awards for his work.Roots and Shoots UK is an education programme of the Jane Goodall Institute . It encourages young people to implement practical positive change for people, animals and the environment.The Shimna Roots and Shoots group started in September last year and comprises  students and three staff members.Its mission is to allow young people to connect with, experience and develop a love for the natural world.The group has also adopted Donard Wood, which borders the school grounds, and is working hard to keep it and surrounding areas litter free..prettyPhoto

title: Twinning group boost to PIPS Hope charity
story: THE work of a local charity which provides a support service and offers counselling for anyone who faced with dficulties in their le ranging from depression to suicidal thoughts and self-harm has been boosted by a local twinning group.The Rowallane and Slieve Croob Community Twinning Group has presented PIPS Hope and Support representatives with a cheque for pound.The money was raised at a recent Festival of Celtic Music and Ceilidh Dance at the Millbrook Lodge Hotel in Ballynahinch.The festival showcased local cultural talent and included harp melodies played by Abi Campbell, a medley of Highland Dance performed by The Heart of Down Highland Dancers from the Kathryn Stewart School of Highland Dance.The Murray School of Irish Dance also performed at the concert which featured Celtic tunes on the tin whistle by Mrs Michele Murnin, with traditional tunes played by Mary and Joanne Grant from Hilltown and Newry.Mark Rodgers led seven pipers and drummers onto the stage and filled the hotel ballroom with the sound of the perfectly harmonised pipes and drums from the championship-winning Upper Crossgare Pipe Band.The evening also included a performance from special guests from Galicia ndash AC Trubisquintildea mdash who performed the Galician bagpipes, drums and a selection of typical songs and dances accompanied by tambourines.In addition, there were also a number of local arts and crafts groups and local craft businesses who provided colourful exhibits.The evening was brought to a close with a collection organised in aid of PIPS Hope and Support, the twinning grouprsquos designated charity.Twinning group chairwoman Karen Patterson said it chose to focus on PIPS Hope and Support because there has been a high incidence of suicide in the Co Down area and that everyone knew someone who had been affected by mental health issues.She continued: ldquoPIPS Hope and Support delivered a training course for the twinning grouprsquos committee and we are now better equipped to deal with people who can only see suicide as a solution to their problems. We hope our small donation will help provide some counselling sessions to those in need in our local area.ldquoIrsquod also like to pay special thanks to Mrs Colette Clarke, former chairwoman of the Rowallane and Slieve Croob Community Twinning Group, for her commitment and dedication to assist with the planning of this wonderful evening. Colettersquos expertise helped make the night a resounding success.Paddy Mageean from PIPS, thanked the twinning group and everyone who supported the recent fundraiser.ldquoWe thank Karen and all at the Rowallane and Slieve Croob Community Twinning Group for selecting PIPS Hope and Support to be the beneficiary of the fantastic festival of Celtic Music and Ceilidh Dance which raised pound. We are grateful to everyone who attended, sponsored or donated to the event, showing their support for us.Paddy said all the funds raised for the charity help support people with issues affecting their quality of le and provides education programmes to people on how they can help reduce the risk of suicide in the community..prettyPhoto

title: Whistle Down The Wind premiere is a triumph
story: DOWNPATRICKrsquoS St Patrickrsquos Choral Society recently finished a successful local premiere of the musical Whistle Down The Wind by Andrew Lloyd-Webber and Jim Steinman to captivated audiences in the Downshirersquos Great Hall last week.The production ran from last Wednesday to Saturday and boasted a cast and crew of more than  volunteers, all of whom have been working hard since September to bring this piece of theatre to le for the first time in Downpatrick.The musical premiegravered in  at the National Theatre in Washington, DC, and a concept album was released in . It was produced in the West End in  and has been revived several times since then and toured extensively.It features well known songs such as No Matter What, made famous by Boyzone in the s. Other hits include Vaults Of Heaven, When Children Rule The World, A Kiss Is A Terrible Thing To Waste and of course the title song, Whistle Down The Wind.Director Simon Pyper said: ldquoIt was a truly heartwarming experience to present this little known price of theatrical gold to an audience.ldquoThe feedback was wonderful and our cast had a fantastic experience, especially our wonderfully talented childrenrsquos ensemble of almost  kids who proved that there will be no shortage of talent in the local region in future years.As one curtain falls, another rises for St Patrickrsquos as it is now already planning a summer scheme production which will run from August -, as well as their spring  production.Keep up to date with all upcoming events and information on how to join by following St Patrickrsquos Choral Society on Facebook and online..prettyPhoto

title: outstanding quality at second calf fair
story: Breed judges from throughout the UK and Ireland were unanimous in their praise for the Pedigree Calf Fair and Beef NI Expo, held at the Balmoral Showgrounds in Belfast on SaturdaySpeaking after the one-day show, which featured three show rings and  native and continental beef breeds, event organiser and Chairman, David Connolly said: ldquoItrsquos been another fantastic event, and we certainly exceeded our strap-line lsquoBigger and Betterrsquo.ldquoThe  show has surpassed last yearrsquos inaugural event, attracting hundreds of spectators and more than  trade exhibits. Cattle entries were on a par with last year, and the judges were all impressed with the quality of the calves and the high level of stockmanship.ldquoOur judges have been busy throughout the day, and all were in agreement that the show provides a  for the provincersquos pedigree beef champions of tomorrow.
